name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Jørn Dohrmann, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the implementation of Regulation 1/2005 on the protection of animals during transport within and outside the EU (2018/2110(INI)) (A8-0057/2019).

name: Jørn Dohrmann
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! Dear colleagues! The day has come when Parliament finally has to take a stand on a matter that I have spent quite a long time working on in order to promote. Parliament now has the chance to demand to the Commission and the Member States that they must do more to ensure animal welfare during transport. First of all, I would like to thank my colleagues from the other groups with whom I have negotiated. When the work on the report was about to start, I said that I wanted all parties involved and that they should also be consulted so that we could ensure as strong a support for the report as possible, not only for our sake, but for the sake of animals. Now there is no more work to do this time, and I therefore hope that my colleagues have also felt involved in the creation of the report. In any case, I would like to express my gratitude for the many constructive proposals and their great cooperation. This has meant that today we stand here and can say that we have made an effort for the many millions of animals transported in and out of the European Union. Today is a good day for animals, and that is because we are calling for the transport times for live animals to be reduced and reduced. We want stricter and more systematic controls on transport and harsher penalties for those who break the rules and weaken animal welfare. On the whole, we want to transport fewer live animals. Instead, we'd rather transport frozen meat. And now that we're already talking about animals, so I'd like laws to address the elephant in the room. The report demands that we stop exporting live animals for slaughter to third countries if these countries do not impose the same animal welfare requirements as we have in the European Union. And for some, that is a controversial requirement. In a Danish newspaper, I could read a statement from an EPP member who calls the claim extremist! If it is an extremist to walk away from a practice where animals are stranded at EU border crossings and are tightly crammed together, thirsty and overheated for several days in a row, mind you, then you can call me an extremist. I'd even like to take it as a badge of honor. I myself have been between Bulgaria and Turkey at the border and made a random check of lorries, and there we found that one stood six hours just to get the paperwork done. And you could also say that they stood in the sun without shade, it was hot, there was 30-35 degrees. It was noted that calves had been born on the way, and therefore it was also found that they were animals without eartags, the animals had therefore ended up in no man's land. In fact, we send animals on a journey where they become lawless. In this house, where it is thought that almost everything is regulated, it is a little incomprehensible to me that, for example, a member of the EPP Group goes so far as to call this an exaggeration. Because there are no rules at all for these animals, which end up in Turkey and the Middle East, for example. It must come to an end, so I would urge all Members to vote in favour of paragraph 88. Making such a requirement would be a mark of tightening up the rules and that it is high time we lifted our animal welfare ambitions. That is the signal we are sending with this report. Now it will be up to the Commission and the Member States to follow suit. We already have some good rules on paper. However, they are wrong to comply with them in the individual countries. We can see how some Member States do not carry out checks on lorries and consignments of animals at all. This means that there are countries where legislation has not actually existed at all. It degrades animal welfare but also distorts competition in the internal market. We also have countries that report completely unrealistically high levels of control to the Commission. They also cover non-applicable legislation. This is where we need to correct this! I am therefore pleased that the Commission itself has admitted that more needs to be done in terms of reporting and control. The Commission's own representative himself has admitted this at the hearing I organised in December. It is a group of the report's recommendations, on which it is already being acted upon, in the light of it. It's a good start! Now the Commission just has to make sure that we respond to the remaining recommendations that this Parliament has hopefully made. So it's time we got behind the animals.

name: Karin Kadenbach
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has In the European Parliament, when we talk about animals, we are talking about sentient beings. And if we look at the transport of animals within the European Union and, above all, those with objectives outside the European Union, then the suspicion must be confirmed that animals are not regarded as sentient beings. If we see them crammed together at 30, 40, 50 degrees at the ports of loading, when we see them without food, if we see calves that have not yet been breastfed, how they are really screaming and whining, then that is simply a look away that we must not allow in the future. We have framework conditions which, as Mr Dohrmann has already said, are not complied with in many Member States, which are not controlled and which, when they are controlled, are subject to sanctions which, as a rule, can be more or less out of the postage coffers. In other words, we really need a great deal of attention here, because under the one health approach – this one health – it is not only about the health and well-being of animals, but also about human health. We know that when animals are under great stress before slaughter, for example, this also has a negative impact on the quality of meat and thus also negatively on human consumption. I am really asking for an improvement as soon as possible.

name: Keith Taylor
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, it’s no secret that animal welfare protection is practically non-existent in transport. Animals are crammed into old and broken trailers, squashed against the ceilings and piled on top of each other with no access to water. It’s a distressing sight but one that is all too commonplace. We find ourselves, a decade on from the regulation’s introduction, with the same breaches being reported time and time again. Nothing has changed. Additionally, prolonged delays at third-country border controls can last for hours, or sometimes even days and in stifling heat, resulting in horrific suffering and fatalities among the animals – and this despite the judgment by the Court of Justice that transporters must observe the regulations even if their destination is beyond the EU borders. I look forward to supporting Mr Dohrmann’s report and I would urge my colleagues to do so. The Member States have the authority to carry out the regulations and they must enforce them more strictly.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it’s a pleasure to be here today. I believe today’s report is another step towards improving implementation of the regulation on animal welfare during transport. Let me begin by saying that animal welfare in general, and the protection of animals during transport more specifically, has been a priority under this Commission, and you know very well that we have addressed a lot of the issues in this area. That said, when the Court of Auditors presented its report at last December’s meeting of Parliament’s Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals (Animal Welfare Intergroup), it was clear that, despite progress achieved, there are issues that need to be addressed: in particular, proper implementation of legislation and enforcement of rules. There is no doubt. At the Intergroup meeting I summarised some of the actions we have taken in this important and sensitive area. In addition, I outlined our efforts to address three areas where we still see a need for improvement: first, exporting animals by road in extreme temperatures; second, exporting animals by sea; and third, the transport of un-weened calves. The Commission is addressing these issues from several angles. Its work covers a number of the issues raised in today’s report, and it involves subgroups of the EU Platform on Animal Welfare set up to work specifically on these issues and find common solutions. This work is being done by the Member States, animal welfare NGOs and industry representatives – and I see NGO representatives here – as well as independent scientific experts. The Commission regularly organises meetings with the Member States’ national contact points for animal welfare during transport. These face-to-face meetings facilitate discussions on better implementation and enforcement on the ground. The national contact points also contributed to the European Federation of Veterinarians’ guidelines on evaluating whether cattle, pigs and horses are fit for transport. The Commission has conducted audits in Member States that export animals by road and sea, and this process has covered incidents reported by NGOs and visits to some of the most relevant ports. It is following up on these audits so that Member States address the problems identified. The Commission is now producing an overview report on the situation. The conclusions and recommendations will concern all Member States. Last summer, Commission staff also visited the border between Bulgaria and Turkey in order to monitor the situation there, and I am committed to maintaining pressure in that respect, including in the season ahead. I am pleased there have been some improvements in the implementation of official controls. In 2018, summer exports of live cattle by road decreased and the compliance rate of trucks at the border increased, as the audit showed, and of course the Court of Auditor’s report mentions this too. However, I acknowledge that weaknesses remain. The Commission will work with the relevant bodies to resolve them. The Commission, and I personally, have written several times to all the Member States governments informing them about, and asking them to monitor, the situation if temperatures are very high. We have requested that they respect temperature requirements and properly implement the rules to protect animals during road and sea transport. Last month I met the Turkish Minister for Agriculture to discuss the export of cattle. At this meeting I raised a number of welfare issues, including long waiting times at the border and the need for structural improvement at the border. We need to address this issue of structural development from both sides, and especially to ask Turkey to act as swiftly as possible, and to highlight the need for control points in Turkey so that European transporters comply with EU animal welfare rules. Our interventions have had some effect but it is clear we are not yet there. We need to continue our work, and we will. The Commission has already started to address the recommendations in the Court of Auditors’ report. We have begun a review of the various Member States’ reports and the results of their official controls. This will generate more consistent data, which, when analysed, will paint a more reliable picture of animal welfare during transport. Today’s resolution also highlights the need for more reliable data. I must remind you, however, that Member States have the primary responsibility for implementing the regulation. Just to mention the situation with third countries: the Commission is active in raising animal welfare issues at International Animal Health Organisation level and in relation to the Better Training for Safer Food initiative; and, in our trade agreements, we also push strongly on issues affecting annual welfare. The Commission’s actions are intended to help achieve better implementation and enforcement. At December’s meeting of the Animal Welfare Intergroup, I assured those present that the EU will continue to monitor the situation closely. We will consider further options to enforce the rules if need be. I would like to repeat those assurances now, and, above all, I want to stress that the Commission and the Member States must continue working together in order to improve the welfare of animals during transport.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: drafts member of the Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, over the last few months we have been working in the Committee on Petitions on a text reflecting the public's complaints about the conditions for the transport of live animals in the Union, reflecting the serious shortcomings in the implementation of the Regulation on animal transport. There are three main issues among our concerns: the systematic violation of the rules requiring adequate conditions of transport for live animals, especially medium and long distance animals, which infringes legal equality between Member States; the absence of reliable data on the conditions of transport and control of the vehicles carrying the reses; and finally, constant impunity and lack of sanctions in many states. In the end, the consequences of this lack of control over the application of the law result not only in flagrant cases of animal abuse, but also in unfair competition between animal transport undertakings, clearly permitted by certain countries of this Union, and in a lack of control over the conditions which ends up having an impact on the health of European consumers.

name: Sofia Ribeiro
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, there is a directive in which all assessments are extremely positive and have allowed a huge improvement in the reduction of animal suffering during their movement, as well as in the allocation of better physical conditions for means of transport. As less positive aspects we have some lack of commitment on the part of some Member States, the lack of harmonisation of the systems of fines within the European Union, which should be more severe and more punitive for those who are predatory, and equivalent throughout the European area. We also have problems in some third countries of lack of respect for European requirements, that is a fact. However, we cannot transport this debate to the ideological field, nor take advantage of the proximity of the European elections so that a radical agenda can be passed, which does nothing more than bring discredit to this meritorious directive, without positive consequences for the animals transported. Aspects such as strengthening inspections, the impossibility of transporting animals that are not in optimal health conditions, which should be slaughtered, where possible, as close to the farms where they are, the possible creation of a mobile network of killers to avoid long transport, as well as the incentive to transport meat and carcasses, rather than live animals , deserve our support and purpose. Nevertheless, we cannot accept that the transport of live animals should simply be eliminated from The European area and from European exports. We do not all live in the centre of Europe and we must have the utmost respect for peripheral countries and geographical discontinuity and we cannot call into question the love that farmers have for their animals, nor do we think they are responsible for the mistreatment.

name: Nicola Caputo
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, animals are sentient beings. Every year millions of animals are transported to Member States and to third countries over long distances to be reared or slaughtered, exposed to suffering for hours in small available spaces, unsustainable temperatures, without food and water, and withstanding the high demands of the movement of vehicles, which are often obsolete.  Animal journey times must be reduced, of course, and we must have a strategy in this regard. One solution could be, for example, the restoration of local slaughterhouses, local slaughter facilities. In view of the appalling number of reports of unsuitable vehicles used to transport live animals, both by land and sea, It is necessary for Member States to apply strict certification and type-approval procedures, and also to improve the fitness checks of animals before loading. It is essential that the future CAP maintains the link between payments and the best animal welfare conditions, in accordance with the standards set out in Regulation (EC) No 1/2005.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments.  At the outset, I would like to thank the report's author, Mr Dohrmann, and his colleagues for doing an excellent job. At the same time, I would like to remind you that in December 2012, Parliament adopted a resolution by MEP Janusz Wojciechowski, now a member of the ECA, calling on the Commission to enforce the same conditions for the transport of animals throughout the Union. Moreover, he then called on the Commission to reduce the transport time for animals for slaughter to eight hours.  Unfortunately, to date, progress in implementing this 2005 Council Regulation to prevent unnecessary suffering from animals during transport is insufficient in all Member States. I support the report's call on the Commission to review this regulation and to detail the requirements for the transport of animals. Furthermore, the Commission should ensure that the provisions of the Regulation are enforced and implemented in a harmonised and uniform manner throughout the Union, in particular as regards the ability of animals to travel. The Polish delegation in the EKR will support this report.

name: Fredrick Federley
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you to colleagues and the rapporteur, Mr Dohrmann, for your very good work. When we have worked on these texts, there has been a great deal of agreement between the political groups. It is rare that we manage to get as far as precisely on the issues of animal welfare and how we deal with the animals that exist in the European Union. We also know from the Eurobarometer presented last year in February that one of the issues that European citizens want us to work more on is to ensure the protection of animals that exist in the European Union. That is also why it is possible, for example, for the GUE and the EPP, even to sign the same kind of compromise here, which is a major step forward and demonstrates a political willingness to act on behalf of the citizens. Every year, 1.37 billion animals are transported within the EU or outside the EU's borders. At the same time, we see that there is total disdain for the Member States to carry out checks and ensure that the legislation in force applies. We also know that if you break this, there will be virtually no consequences whatsoever. We would need a Commission that takes this task seriously, which is also contained in our founding treaties for the European Union. I am therefore pleased that today we are criticising the European Parliament, that is to say that it is time for the European Ombudsman to look at whether the Commission really fulfils the mandate it has in accordance with the Treaties. We know that when the Commission really wants something, it can do something. It is not the Commissioner responsible who is the major problem here, but it is colleagues in the Commission who have held back. When there is a change in time and summer and winter time, we can in a few months have concrete legislative proposals that affect the whole of the Union. But here – as far as animal welfare is concerned – we have not made a single step forward in five years. We have not seen a new strategy for animal welfare. We have not been given a common basic law on animal welfare, and these scandals are continuing. This must be stopped in the next parliamentary term, at the latest.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, millions of animals are being towed every day in lorries, planes and ships across Europe, and far beyond. And the Commissioner says: 'In Europe, almost 100% of all animal transports comply with European rules.' He said it again this morning. And that's absolutely not true. It's a big lie. Organizations such as Eyes on Animals, Animals International, Animal Welfare Foundation, Animals' Angels, have written hundreds of reports in ten years full of evidence of transports of sick and injured animals, outright animal cruelty, overcrowded trucks, lack of water, transport at extreme temperatures. Mr President, these are not incidents. This is daily practice in Europe. Last summer I went to see for myself in Slovenia and Croatia. Trucks drove off and on to supply ramshackle ships. The animals were dirty, injured and succumbed to the heat. And as an absolute low point, we saw in the port of Rasa a young bull that ran between shore and ship, and was loaded on one leg by a crane on board a ship. The animal was then forced on board with electroshocks. I will never forget this image. Commissioner, we have also shown you these images. Are you lying there, like me, awake at night? And what did you do after that? Have you already started infringement proceedings against Croatia? Why not? What else do you need to take action? You also know that newborn animals are transported for days, when they do not know how to use the installations and therefore cannot drink them? You also know that the millions of animals that are shipped to the Middle East and to North Africa after a long, long journey end up in absolute hell? When do you take the concerns of millions of citizens and Parliament seriously and take action? We must stop these terrible animal transports together and we can start today. Vote for the report and put an end to those long, miserable animal transports.

name: Thomas Waitz
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Contrary to what Commissioner Andriukaitis claims in a frightening regularity, not everything is in order when it comes to transporting animals on Europe's roads. And I would say that this report proves definitively that European laws are not being complied with when transporting animals, especially when it comes to exporting animals to third countries – to Russia, Turkey or Lebanon. The European Court of Justice has clearly ruled that European laws apply to the point of destination, and transport that does not comply with these provisions must be prohibited.  If Mrs Ribeiro of the Conservatives were to suggest that it is a radical policy to demand that European laws be complied with, then I would like to make radical policies. Nor do I think it is radical to advocate a reduction in animal transport times in order to prevent animal suffering as much as possible. I would also ask members of the European People's Party to vote in favour of our report today, at least for those who also have a heart for animals.

name: Marco Zullo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have said this and laughed at it: millions of animals are subjected every year to the stress of long journeys in precarious conditions, for lack of food and water, for too high or too low temperatures, for overcrowding. And all this causes anguish and suffering, and even the premature death of some of these animals.  The protection of animals during transport today is still inefficient. That's a fact. There is no common standard of treatment, nor is there a common standard of controls, which are different in quantity and quality. It is incredible to think that there are states in the European Union today where the number of controls is zero.  In order to shed light on all this, we had called for a committee of inquiry, but this request was rejected by the political groups in this Parliament. Fortunately, however, we have been able to discuss this in various committees and we have made it clear and determined that regular and thorough checks and inspections must be carried out, with strict penalties for infringements, because there are rules that exist today and are not respected. The presence of specialised personnel and state-of-the-art animal welfare technologies must be guaranteed. These civilised measures must be enforced through bilateral agreements, including with regard to third countries, leading to a ban on trade if necessary. However, we want to be even more ambitious, and that is why, ladies and gentlemen, I ask you to support the amendment limiting the maximum transport period for live animals to eight hours. We must do everything possible to avoid any suffering.

name: Harald Vilimsky
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. There is the proposition that the degree of civilization of a culture is determined by how it deals with animals. If we look at Europe in particular with farm animals, I can only say that there is a great deal wrong here. How animals are transported from one country through many other countries, often for many hours, days, often even through extreme heat, I can only say: this would be one of the examples where the European community of states is called upon to implement a set of rules here in order to prevent precisely that. Just think of how half-dead carcasses are still being shipped alive in southern Europe across the Mediterranean towards the Middle East, towards North Africa. This is where such suffering is being created that I say that there is an urgent need to stop here.  Many years ago we had the discussion that eight hours is enough in terms of transport length. I will also ask for this, because I hope that, at least with this generous deadline, the European People's Party will also be able to agree. If it were up to me, four hours of transport maximum would already be sufficient.  What I am also trying to do, which is particularly important to me, is that we finally implement an export ban to third countries, so that these very images of animals being transported to Turkey, Russia, the Middle East and North Africa, are finally a thing of the past. I can only hope that you will also have enough heart to give your assent here.

name: Sophie Montel (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every year one billion poultry and 37 million cattle, pigs, sheep and equines are transported alive in the European Union and to third countries. Worryingly, only 1% of these animals are being transported. Numerous investigations, including by CIWF, show that abuses are legion. The legislation is absolutely not respected: excessive transport time, inadequate equipment, animals piled on top of each other. The result is that these poor beasts are, at best, dehydrated, starving, stressed, weakened, when they do not end up beaten, trampled, asphyxiated, mutilated, or, by death. This situation cannot continue, we must ensure that there are more controls and that much harsher sanctions are applied in order to force compliance with the regulations. Having said that, ladies and gentlemen, the best solution is to avoid transporting animals over long distances. The European Union, which is multiplying free trade treaties, is of course bearing a heavy responsibility for this disastrous situation, which leads to ever more animal abuse. Intensive breeding and overproduction are also sources of animal abuse and suffering and, again, the European Union encourages this system. It's time, ladies and gentlemen, to get your reason back.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Union has the highest animal welfare standards in the world, including their transport. They have been rooted for many years in the common agricultural policy, which makes the payment of subsidies conditional on farmers completing them. Of course, this does not mean that the situation is perfect and abuse does not happen. Nevertheless, a clear distinction should be made here between the responsibilities of breeders and companies transporting animals. Animal welfare rules must be respected in both breeding and transport. In transport, we should increase the requirements as to the conditions under which animals are transported, which affects or determines transport time. We must therefore strengthen the control system and punish those who do not comply with animal transport standards.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. A society is always judged by how it deals with the weakest, by the very weakest. These can be humans, but they are also often animals, and the most vulnerable are animals on the transport routes. Because there they are not in the local stable, there they are not with the farmer, who normally takes care of them, there they are often lawless and often ownerless. We must make it clear that this weakness of animals is not being exploited by the EU. The EU has a responsibility, and the EU must take care of it. We clearly need transport times, which are limited to eight hours. We must finally get to know that we should transport meat and not live animals. We need regional slaughterhouses again, absolutely regional cycles, we need restrictions at high temperatures, we absolutely need the transport restriction for unremoved calves and unconditional bans on ships that are not designed for the transport of animals. Mühldorf is close to the district of Rosenheim, and Mühldorf has distinguished itself by the recent halt to such transport. A cow should go on 5 000 km of drive – a pregnant cow! This was stopped by the Veterinary Office. And I say: that was responsibility!

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Whenever the issue of animal transport is raised, arguments are raised that some Member States have not made progress in implementing the regulation. It is therefore not necessary to focus on the creation of ideological principles, which are often unworkable, but to create and enforce practical rules that respond to the needs of today's animal transport market and their general good. I consider paragraphs 59, 63, 77, 83 and 88 of our report to be imworkable. Dear! Farmers cannot be made responsible for the transport of animals. Farmers breed and care for animals. This is their source of income. Typically, animals are transported by farmers only on their own farms. The rapporteur said: it is time for us to support animals. Of course, let us support animals, but above all, let us support the farmers who breed these animals, and let us also support and create real rules to enable the normal transport of animals within Europe.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the EU Regulation 1/2005 aims to protect animals in transport. However, this regulation is not consistently complied with in many Member States – we all know that. The evidence for years has been on the table, but so far the Commission has not responded with infringement proceedings. On the contrary, the Commission is even downplaying the breaches of the law. Commissioner, why are you blind and deaf when it comes to animals, when existing rules on the protection of animals are being broken? Why do you clearly disregard Article 13 of the Treaty of Lisbon? I say this to you: because you and the Commission are going to the aisle of the agricultural associations, because the interests and the protection of animals are always assessed from behind. The interests of agriculture are always valued above consistent animal welfare.  And let us tell the truth: the Commission is also following the wishes of the European Council. Animal welfare has no place there at all. As a result, European policy as a whole bears the greatest share of the blame for the miserable treatment of animals. Ladies and gentlemen, do not make this report a toothless tiger! Vote for the animal-friendly proposals!

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, about a year ago to the day, 223 parliamentarians called here for a commission of inquiry into the conditions of transport of animals within the European Union. The presidents of the groups, particularly the right and the Socialists, opposed this commission of inquiry and blocked the possibility that we had to check the real conditions in which the animals are transported. So in fact, when I hear here a number of Members, left or right, come and explain to us that we need to improve, etc., I say that we make fun of the mondeǃ We don't care about the world, mr. Commissaireǃ Simply because the suffering of animals does not matter, because the suffering of animals weighs nothing but the profits of the agri-food in our society. And that's the scandaleǃ So be careful, be careful because if this Parliament or the leaders are not interested, it is of interest to citizens, NGOs and journalists. And we are deepening, through this inaction, the gap that exists between European institutions and citizens. So be careful not to continue in this dehumanized world, which means that we lose all our values of solidarity with the suffering of animals.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF).
text: Mr President, I support this initiative, which has resulted in a balanced report and common sense proposals. We need to clarify the application of the rules for the transport of live animals, because this is a subject that has a negative impact on the whole European meat sector and, as always, it is the farmers who pay the consequences. We are concerned about the distortions of competition that may exist between our countries, but let us recognize them where they really are. Firstly, distortions in production costs, which require segmenting the birth, breeding and slaughter between different places and thus multiplying the journeys. Distortions also in transport costs, between countries that have complied with the rules for years and those that do not. Distortions in slaughter costs, which lead to the transport of animals ever further away from the places of breeding and consumption. Finally, distortions induced by a liberalised foreign trade policy with third countries that do not respect our health standards and render our animal welfare efforts useless. So let's stop importing animals that we don't want. Let us support alternatives at the local level that will revitalise the forgotten territories and affirm to our citizens that no, farmers are not responsible for animal suffering.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ten years after this EU animal transport regulation, we are now discussing that it is not being complied with. What kind of joke is this if we are now changing the rules ourselves and there are no controls and no sanctions? Will everything continue as before? It is clear that anyone who has a pet or who is a farmer knows that an animal has feelings, that an animal is in pain, that an animal can feel suffering, that an animal can feel joy. Why do we not go so far as to require these transport companies carrying out animal transports to have a licence? This license for transport must be revoked if the conditions are not met. That would be consistent eu action. It is good that the rules are being improved. However, there is no point in improving the rules and not complying with them. Therefore, drastic sanctions must be imposed on those responsible for the murder of millions of animals every year.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Listening to the debate here, I have the impression that there is not a single proper transport of animals in Europe, and that is not true at all. We have exemplary legislation in Europe and the majority of transports are carried out properly. The previous speaker should also know that there is already a licence for the transport of animals. But, of course, there are also problems, and we must tackle the problems. There is also a European Citizens' Initiative – more than a million people have signed because they do not agree with some of what is happening today. In principle, we in this House must also ask ourselves how we deal with these citizens' initiatives as a whole. That is why I think we have to look at the subject, we have to look at where things are not going well. Above all, we have to look at how to create local cycles, because there really is no point in carting animals for slaughter through half of Europe, just to continue the search for the even cheaper slaughterhouse somewhere in Europe. Of course, it makes sense to slaughter the animals locally and then transport the meat. So we are trying to implement today's legislation sensibly and to ensure that Europe is exemplary in this area.

name: Tilly Metz (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thousands of kilometers, hours of driving without enough space, often without adapted access to water, if at all. Waiting in the heat, in the cold, fear, stress: this is the fate of thousands of animals every day – millions a year. But come on, we no longer look away and stop letting these atrocities happen. It's different. I don't want to convince you all to become vegetarians. But support us to have better, stricter regulations and more controls on the transport of live animals!  We are responsible for what we do. We are also responsible for what we do not do. Animal transport cannot, of course, be seen separately from EU agricultural policy, where profit is still – or I would have to say – the focus is on profit. Not only do we need an energy transition, we also need an agricultural turnaround. Away from mass animal husbandry, away from mass production, towards sustainable agriculture, where animal welfare is not only nice to have, but an obligation.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by You have devoted 26 pages to provide pigs with a pleasant access to the slaughter. And what? – of course, we have driver's licenses here, further checks, shortening transport to eight hours. It's people who drive longer. You can't enforce existing laws, and you want to introduce more. This is typical here for you, for the European Union. You are creating a problem yourself, first by banning slaughter on the spot, by regulating slaughterhouses, by issuing such regulations that these slaughterhouses are centralised and as a result animals have to be transported far away, and then you are fighting the effects of your own regulations in the form of long transports of animals and you are issuing further regulations that they will not be able to enforce. In addition, who says it? That's what people who have barbaric laws at home that allow the murder of unborn children and such barbarians will instruct us about transporting animals? No, it won't. You call the child a congloter of cells, and the pig is not a sausage material for you, but a sentient creature?! Think about where your priorities are. Someone says you're going to support animals. So I hope that it will be the animals who will vote for those who do so at the next election.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: (start of off-mic intervention)... Mr President, I am really angry. Every year, millions of animals in Europe suffer appalling transport conditions: locked up, exploited and abused. We can no longer turn a blind eye to animal abuse. Animals have the right to respect and benevolence, just like human beings. Last year, for example, several NGOs showed that 70% of the trucks inspected at the Bulgarian border do not comply with EU law. We must shed light on these shameful practices through a commission of inquiry, even if the Socialists and Conservatives do not want them. It is time for us to put animal welfare back at the heart of our work, reduce the maximum travel time and ban EU animal exports to third countries. Colleagues, the watchword is very simple: if you have not understood that it is high time to defend the lives of animals rather than the interests of the agri-food industry, then you have not understood anything. Now we will have to take your courage with both hands and make sure to support this commission of inquiry, because it is proposed for good reasons, but above all because it is necessary and useful.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am ready to support this report and thank the authors for it. For more than a year I have been dealing with the problem of transporting animals around Europe from the point of view of the Czech Republic. I am in contact with the non-governmental sector and from the facts I have, Commissioner, I must say that my view is completely opposite to yours. I absolutely don't share your optimism. And only information for you – 3,000 cows were exported to Turkey from the Czech Republic in 2013. In 2015 and 2016, it was already 78,000 cows. Cattle exports from this Member State to Turkey have multiplied, we have clear facts and information on how EU legislation is not being respected, how there is no control at the Bulgarian-Turkish border. These are facts you can't question here. Your Animal Rights Commission has done nothing. I have written to the Commission many times as a Czech MEP about the smuggling of dogs and cats from the Czech Republic to Western Europe, I have not received any replies. So, please, let's pay more attention to animal rights in the future.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the protection of animals during transport within and outside the European Union has been the subject of many petitions in the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions and is an issue that raises concerns. And it raises concerns, of course, because there is an issue with animal health and, by extension, with human health. I therefore believe that we must be decisive and that checks should also be carried out at the border. I would also like you, Commissioner, to see the issue that exists in relation to the transport of animals from Skopje to Greece. First of all, we have illegal Greekizations. These animals appear as supposedly Greek and from then on they are stacked in trucks to be transported from Skopje to Thessaloniki or Athens. This is a serious matter and you must also intervene in this regard. There needs to be scrutiny on this issue.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, every year more than four hundred thousand animals are transported alive. And many of them, too many, over long distances without food or water and at extreme temperatures. Unnecessary suffering that popular and socialists have refused to investigate in this House, as asked by the European greens. Commissioner, the current European regulation on animal transport is absolutely inefficient and does not even guarantee compliance with its own standards. As it shows, one fact: in 2007 the controls have been halved and thus the non-compliance has doubled. Commissioner, it is time to force the Member States to fulfil their obligations and not to allow further abuse. It is time to limit the transport of animals and to ban them when it does not guarantee their welfare. From Equo, European greens will continue to work to end animal abuse, whether in transport, industrial livestock or macro gear. No more animal abuse.

name: John Stuart Agnew (ENF).
text: – Mr President, there is quite adequate legislation on animal transport: the problem is that it isn’t being enforced, and here we find a cultural difference. In the north—west of Europe, there are a lot of people who are very concerned about animal welfare. In the UK we have a charity called the Royal Society for the Protection of Animals that brings private prosecutions against people who don’t treat animals properly. But the further south—east you go in Europe, the more the culture changes, and they are less interested. These are the people who are expected to enforce the legislation, and they simply can’t be bothered. On another subject, in the course of my life I have offloaded thousands of sheep from lorries, and I can tell you that the ones that travel best are the ones that travel empty. They do not need to be packed full of food. If they are, then what happens on the lorry is that they go into the rumination process, with urination and defecation, and make a mess of the lorry and particularly the sheep on the lower decks. You do not need to fill a sheep full of food for it to travel comfortably.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, millions of live animals are transported every year, both between the countries of the European Union and to third countries. We all know that during transport these animals suffer, suffer, suffer risks to their lives and, above all, travel for a long time under bad weather conditions, stacked in means which often do not meet the standards. You will tell me that the way man behaves in animals is a result of his character, personality and cultural level. But the states must address this problem. They must establish standards, implement these standards and punish offenders. We must also avoid moving animals to third countries that do not meet the standards. Finally, the smuggling of animals must also be tackled. Illegal animals come to Greece from Turkey, Albania and Skopje, which do not meet safety and hygiene standards and endanger the lives of consumers.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the protection of animals during transport is, of course, a sensitive matter. I agree that meat should be transported, not live animals. But if necessary, then there must be strict regulations, strict standards that the EU has, and these must first of all be required, enforced, checked. I am opposed to new regulations if we are not able to comply with and enforce existing regulations that are strict enough. Of course, increasing control, controlling at the border is the solution and sanctioning those who do not comply with the appropriate conditions for the transport of animals. Animals should not suffer. However, I am afraid that we cannot ban the transport of animals to third countries, rather really control and require the fulfilment of significantly protective standards.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the transport of live animals is a real problem, which must not be ignored. Transport in breach of animal welfare standards will negatively affect the quality of meat and affect the health of consumers. Member States should strive for the development of slaughter capacity at micro-regional level. Shortening the distance and transport time between farms and slaughterhouses, but in particular between slaughterhouses, processing and disposal centres is essential for ensuring quality products for consumers.  At the same time, however, I express serious reservations about the prohibition of exports to certain countries, as it has disastrous economic consequences for farmers. Instead, viable solutions must be identified to address existing shortcomings and, above all, we must ensure that the current regulations are respected.  At the same time, Middle Eastern countries are the main trading partners for the import of live animals from the European Union. Facilitating slaughter with respect for religious standards in slaughterhouses in the European Union would avoid additional transport costs, which would be profitable for both farmers and consumers.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened carefully to the honourable Members’ contributions and I am grateful for the various insights – and the sometimes very emotional speeches. Let me repeat part of my own speech because, in my introduction, I talked about various ‘issues’ but Ms Hazekamp quoted me in a different way. I repeat: when the Court of Auditors presented its report at last December’s Animal Welfare Intergroup meeting, it was clear that, despite progress achieved, there are issues that need to be addressed. I did not say it was 100% or that we are OK. Why quote what I said in a different way? You know, I like the very simple rule ‘Don’t lie’! And it is clear. We have had meetings and we have discussed the issues that were raised here, about Croatian ports and so on, and we are following the situation and having dialogues with operators. Why are you exaggerating the situation, Ms Hazekamp? Of course I know that now is the time of the European elections and, yes, from an election point of view, your speech was quite good. In recent meetings we have had ongoing exchanges on the current animal welfare situation and, whilst I am proud of the progress we are all making, I am aware that we need to do more. We have no chance to say ‘job done’. No. The job has not been done. I am now very worried about criminal activity – about crime and fraud – and you can see new examples of this. We need to discuss penalties and other issues, of course. But don’t ignore the situation at the Commission, where we are doing a lot in the area of animal welfare. The Commission’s number one priority in this area is, and will remain, better enforcement. I repeat, better enforcement. And we will continue: it is not sufficient to have a good legal framework to protect our animals if we do not ensure it is correctly applied. However, the Commission cannot achieve better implementation and enforcement by working alone. It is up to Member States and operators: and, of course, I invite Members of the European Parliament to discuss these issues with your respective countries’ governments. You have a good opportunity to organise debates at different levels. We are also debating these issues at the EU Animal Welfare Platform, and we have achieved many steps forward. Please read once again Mr Wojciechowski’s report on animal welfare from the Court of Auditors. It takes an objective view both of certain improvements and also with regard to where we can do more. That is clear. But all of us – the Commission, Member States and representatives of civil society – must work together. It is a pity that, after the emotional speeches, no one from the Green Group is in the Chamber. It would be good to continue our conversation, and not just to deliver emotional speeches. (Applause) I am pleased that this report makes recommendations to both the Commission and Member States. I strongly believe we share the same goal: to ensure that animals, as sentient beings, do not suffer unnecessarily. Of course it’s true that we need to do more. But let us continue to work to achieve this – not blaming and shaming all the time. That is not the constructive way. (Applause)

name: Jørn Dohrmann
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! Thanks for the comments. Thank you to the Commissioner also for his words, who says that there are still things to work with. There are three priorities that they have set high on the agenda. We are happy to cooperate with the Commissioner. I just have to say: we don't just want it to be talked about! That is why we would like to see this report. We are lagging behind other countries like New Zealand and Australia. You have long taken the stock on this, and I miss a little in the comment that the Commissioner made: where did the new technology go? Why do we not use new technology to keep an eye on this area? I think that is important! We are also talking about the eight hours of transport. I say that it must be as short as possible, and I do so on the outset that I do not want it to be planned all of a sudden that all animals have to go on an eight-hour journey. So therefore as short as possible! I am confident that the majority in this House today will send this strong signal to the Commission, and that is why I think it is also time for us to stand behind the animals. I would therefore like to thank you very much for this debate and thank you for your support so far.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 14 February 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am critical of the protection of animals during transport within and outside the EU. In my opinion, it is unacceptable that, 13 years after the entry into force of the Regulation on this subject, there are still very numerous cases of mistreatment of animals during transport, which causes suffering to animals, poses a threat to their health, but also to humans. The most common infringements of the rules in force, after all, concern overcrowding and insufficient space intended for animals during transport, non-compliance with watering and feeding periods of animals and travel time. These phenomena are highly worrying. I call on the European Commission and its services to enforce the existing rules hard.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. My speech on this subject dear to me is the result of a long-standing commitment, since I am one of the handful of Members who have called for the creation of a commission of inquiry into the transport of live animals. While I regret the refusal that has been taken against us, I nevertheless welcome the work of my colleagues on this report of the utmost importance.  Because what is it about? Some 37 million calves, cows and sheep pass through Europe's roads each year at the cost of appalling suffering. These journeys, sometimes up to seventy hours, are often marked by a cruel lack of hydration, space and oxygen. In 2016, a Video by Eurogroup for Animals had torn the veil of these atrocious abuses.  Weary, I fear that this umpteenth parliamentary report will remain a dead letter, for lack of real political will, not only to enforce existing legislation on the territory of the Union, but also to impose similar standards on our trading partners. At a time when Brussels is preparing to flood the European market with foreign meat, especially Brazilian meat, this last requirement seems destined to remain a wishful thinking.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Virginie Rozière, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on enhancing the competitiveness of the internal market by deepening and managing the EU customs union (2018/2109(INI)) (A8-0059/2019).

name: Virginie Rozière
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today I am presenting an initiative report on a policy which is certainly technical, but which is nevertheless essential to our Union: customs policy. This policy is one of the foundations of the internal market and it is so integrated into the European Union that it is sometimes forgotten its importance. But Brexit is a cruel reminder of this - the customs union and its proper functioning are absolutely vital for the European Union. And this initiative report is part of a series of legislative and non-legislative initiatives relating to the EU customs code, including the reports of my colleagues Selimovic, Grapini and Pospiil. The customs code as we voted in 2013 provided at the time for the establishment of a computer architecture to implement, from 2020, next year, customs procedures dematerialised at European level. Regrettably, we have been forced to extend this deadline to 2025, as part of the Selimovic report, because of delays by the Commission and the Member States in developing and implementing the computer applications needed for these 100% online customs procedures. It is in this context that the report we are discussing today is taking place. This report first stresses the priority of implementing the EU Customs Code. It has been more than ten years since the reform was launched by the Commission in 2008 and this reform is still not fully operational. And it must be quite clear that the new deadlines granted to the Member States and the Commission, respectively 2023 and 2025, to complete the IT architecture are not indicative and that any new lag is absolutely outlawed. So in order to meet these deadlines, the report we are currently discussing calls on the Commission to integrate the constraints and methods of planning and conducting conventional projects - I would say - but which would benefit from being effectively implemented: a definitive definition of specifications, the setting of milestones to facilitate decision-making and clear and permanent reporting. In this regard, the specific report of the European Court of Auditors has clearly shown that these elements, which are essential for the conduct of projects, have so far been lacking and in my opinion their absence largely explains the fact that the objectives are still not being achieved. More broadly, the report we are discussing calls for stronger governance of the 'Douane 2020' programme and future 'Douanes' programmes, particularly for large-scale projects. For this reason, it calls on the Commission to review, at the end - but only at the end - the implementation of the 17 COMPUTER tools, the whole of customs governance, precisely on the drawing board of the report of the European Court of Auditors which I have just mentioned. Therefore, for this purpose, the report I am presenting also encourages the Commission to continue its reflections and work on the tool on the performance of the customs union, as we call on the Commission to work towards a uniform application of customs legislation throughout the European customs territory. There has also been the return of a number of economic operators and customs authorities, who tell us that the implementation of the customs code is not uniform enough today at EU level, which of course leads, first, to potentially costly uncertainty for economic operators, but also and above all to risks to the integrity and proper functioning of the internal market. And I hope that, through this report, the Commission and the Member States will work to ensure a uniform implementation, as I said, of these customs procedures by resorting to the exchange of good practices, joint actions between customs administrations and the establishment of practical guides to strengthen the capacity of the worst-performing Member States on these issues. Finally, and this is an important point for all of us, Parliament must be fully informed of the progress and implementation of the 'Douane 2020' programme and the customs code. We therefore call on the Commission and the Member States, in terms of their responsibility, to further improve the information we have to ensure full parliamentary control over this programme of more than EUR 850 billion, on an essential policy - once again - of the European Union, which has so many implications: Parliament must be fully involved , including in case of difficulty. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and colleagues who this report is widely supported and I hope that it will be equally supported in plenary and that it will be heard by the Commission and the Member States.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable ladies and gentlemen, dear Members, on behalf of Commissioner Moscovici, who cannot be here today, I am happy to present and to be here to discuss with you ways to improve the competitiveness of the internal market by developing the Customs Union. Of course, we would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Rozière, for her report and for the work on this subject. The importance of the Customs Union for the internal market and for the competitiveness of EU companies is, of course, clear. Goods can flow freely, quickly and safely within the European Union thanks to common customs rules at EU external borders. And, at the same time, the EU, the Member States, acting as one single trading bloc in trade negotiations with third countries, have a far stronger position than any Member State alone – as we’ve seen this week, for instance. I would also like to thank you for acknowledging the Customs Union’s vital role and the work carried out by customs administrations in your report. As the report notes, it is vital that the Customs Union ensures the competitiveness of European business, especially the SMEs, while at the same time protecting the EU’s revenue sources and allowing the flow of goods at our external borders. Balancing these objectives is the main goal of the Union Customs Code (UCC). The UCC has been the main legal framework for customs rules since 2016 and it aims to eliminate paperwork and fully automate all customs processes. It also provides for a greater electronic integration between the Member States and it facilitates trade by speeding up customs control. I welcome the reference made in the report to the major progress already achieved over the last 20 years in the digitalisation of our customs processes. The current work is about building and expanding on the existing well—functioning electronic systems. For that reason, the UCC electronic work must proceed carefully, step by step. The new systems will only replace the old ones when they have been fully tested and when they can be launched easily with no disruption to trade. Thanks to the provisional agreement reached in trilogue on the proposal to amend Article 278 of the UCC, the Commission and Member States will have the time necessary to complete their work on the 17 UCC electronic systems. Most systems will in fact be completed by the previously established deadline of 2020. However, for some of them it is necessary to allow extensions up to 2022 for the three national systems and up to 2025 for six trans—European systems. We have proposed these extensions to the Commission to allow traders and Member States to prepare in an efficient way. We believe that the work can now proceed in a smoother way in line with a carefully calibrated and agreed timeline. And, as you request in your report, I can assure you that the Commission’s work programme for the customs IT projects will be regularly updated to take account of the new deadlines. And, besides, we will of course regularly inform Parliament of the progress of the customs electronic projects through regular reports. Greater transparency here is, of course, in everybody’s interest: for you, for the economic operators and for the general public. The Commission already produces annual reports in a technical format on the multiannual strategic plans for customs electronic systems and this form of reporting will continue. And, in addition, under the provisional agreement reached in the trilogue, the Commission will provide a second more strategic annual progress report with the remainder of the work related to the development of the 17 UCC electronic systems. So let me conclude by saying that we will give careful consideration to all the suggestions you made in your report and we intend to address all the customs issues highlighted by this House.

name: Nicola Danti
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Malmström, let me begin by thanking my colleague Virginie Rozière for her excellent work on this report.  As rapporteur for the Committee on International Trade, I would like to highlight a few points on the substance of the text. Firstly, in order to present itself as a credible partner when negotiating trade agreements with third countries, the European Union must have a fully operational customs union that facilitates trade and reduces administrative burdens, particularly for small operators and SMEs.  Secondly, I believe that the protection of citizens and consumers depends first and foremost on our ability to control products entering and circulating in the single market, so as to ensure compliance with standards and standards, both by European companies and by companies outside Europe. This must be done regardless of which country or port of access is, and in order to do this we need to harmonise as far as possible customs procedures, the level and quality of controls, as well as sanctions policies, by strongly hindering the phenomenon of 'port shopping'. In this context, the prospect must be that of an increasing transfer of responsibility from the national customs authorities to the European customs authorities.  Thirdly, digitalisation represents a great opportunity, because it has the potential to make the exchange of information and the payment of duties more transparent and accessible, as well as being a powerful tool for combating corruption at borders.  Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to reiterate that the Brexit process must not have a negative effect on the development or governance of eu customs, as well as on the integrity of the single market.

name: Adam Szejnfeld
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The customs union is one of the cornerstones of the functioning of the European Union as such. Its smooth operation has a major impact, inter alia, on the finances of the European Union, on the activities of entrepreneurs, on consumer safety, which is very important, but also on the European Union's foreign trade with third countries, and – what is the subject of our report – also on competition, the one that exists inside. That is why we, as the European Parliament, must therefore not only deal with the perception of the efficiency of the customs union, but also encourage the Commission to modernise it. There are certainly some important challenges in this regard. The first, which there was a lot of talk about, is modern ICT. We have delays here. They need to be eliminated, but I agree with the Commissioner, the absolute condition is the security of the new systems, not the time when they are introduced. Another issue is the unification of interpretations in the Member States. We must have the same approach to the customs union everywhere, throughout the Union. And the last point, Mr President, which is probably obvious, but it is worth mentioning, the biggest challenge today is Brexit. This will be an examination for the European Union when it comes to the customs union.

name: Daniel Dalton
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I very much welcome this report. We’ve been working for a long time in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) to try and improve customs procedures and the efficiency of trade in Europe. So I strongly support the emphasis on the need for better IT systems to smooth the work of customs authorities and also its call for better managed roll—out of new IT projects by the Commission, working closely with national bodies. Technology, when properly utilised, has the ability to massively reduce the costs and administrative burden of customs procedures in future. Parliament has recognised this for some time, but the Commission has taken eight years to roll this out and also appears reluctant to look at technological solutions in some of the new customs borders that may emerge in the next few weeks, even though there is a clear case for it.  In concrete terms, using technology means cheaper goods for consumers and lower costs of business for traders. The rest of the world is pushing on with tech solutions to customs issues. As trials have already demonstrated, technologies like blockchain have huge potential for even simpler and more secure customs procedures, but we can also help customs authorities by raising the de minimis threshold for e—commerce to the physical limit, not reducing it to zero. Overall, creating a single secure digital place for all parts of the process is the long—term goal, but we’re not quite there yet. As the repeated delays to the implementation of new IT systems in the EU have already shown, getting the Union Customs Code (UCC) going has been a torturous process. But I support the message of this report, which is too important to give up on. The importance of smooth trade flows is too valuable to let technical snags hold up the process for too long.

name: Jasenko Selimovic
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would just like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Ms Rozière, the shadow rapporteurs and the Commission for the good cooperation on this on this report. In order to ensure that we as consumers and citizens of the EU have access to the best, most priceworthy products at all times, it is necessary to ensure that the internal market functions as efficiently as it can, in order to allow trade with the rest of the world and in order to allow distribution across the Union.  As has been mentioned, we have already achieved the agreement on when to digitalise the Union code as fully as was planned from the beginning. But by implementing this opinion, we make sure that the whole custom procedures regulating the market are made as efficient as possible. A functional Customs Union is one of the cores of the Union. By easing bureaucratic burdens and investing in better digital infrastructure, we will improve competitiveness on the market, trading conditions for companies and products for consumers. However, as in most European projects, everything is about the implementation. Therefore, I think this initiative is a necessary step for the creation of a truly seamless Custom Union and single market. This will allow our companies in the Union to take part in a healthy competition, allow us better trade with the rest of the world, be also open to the very investors abroad coming to the Union and increasing competition allows for the best merchandise and products of the season on the internal market, thus ensuring improved quality of the goods that we are buying on an everyday basis. That’s why I welcome the report and congratulate my colleagues on doing it.

name: Tim Aker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it was interesting to read this report as you seem to have more confidence in Britain leaving the European Union than both the UK Government and Mr Robbins, Theresa May’s negotiator. Whereas Recital I identifies that the UK will leave the European Union, Ms May and her negotiator are giving out completely different messages. The latest on the table is the complete fudge of membership of the Customs Union. With it comes permanent loss of sovereignty; we will be leaving in name only. It is now the overwhelmingly popular view of the British people that we must leave the EU without a deal. You could have had a sensible deal based solely on trade but you cling on to hopeless faith that Britain will change its mind, that we will vote again and again and again. That may have worked with Ireland but it won’t work with the United Kingdom.  The clock is ticking down to 29 March. You have time to change your minds and create a deal based solely on a free trade agreement. The eurozone is heading into recession and it will be by your actions that you push it over the edge. (The speaker declined to take a blue—card question from Charles Tannock)

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Union. One thing is clear, even if the British colleague who has just told a lot of nonsense here is now going out: this report is not about Brexit. Unfortunately, it is not the case that Britain has left the European Union, but because people like him, Mr Aker, have told things that they cannot keep today. Anyone who reads the newspapers in the UK today will see that Ford wants to leave the UK precisely because it does not want this unregulated Brexit by 29 March. And Ford is just one of many companies that don't want to go on holiday in the UK, they want to work. That is why the honourable Member from over there should be better at dealing with the matter when he comments on the matter here. But it is true, Mr President – and I am already a little bit advanced in time – that the European Union has collected a total of EUR 3 700 billion in 2017 through tariffs with other countries in the world, thereby covering 15% of its budget. That is a considerable value. We can only congratulate the Commissioner on the fact that this is always possible, even with interesting deals, not only to increase revenue through customs duties, but also to help European companies to have a chance on the world market. Our shadow rapporteur, Adam Szejnfeld, has pointed out that this will only be possible in the future if companies are finally able to do things digitally. There is a lot to improve. We have already done so in other reports – and this is rightly mentioned here. That is where the Member States have to deliver.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: Mr President, a well-functioning customs union is, of course, crucial for a well-functioning European Union. Effective controls and certainly simple, accessible and transparent procedures are important here, and certainly for our SMEs. However, they are being put on hold by delayed use of essential electronic systems. And that's disappointing. If you know that one in 40 jobs in Flanders currently depends on exports to the UNITED Kingdom, then it is important, especially for the Flemish ports, that there is good cooperation from Europe with the British customs services, and certainly after Brexit. In 2017, imports and exports from the European Union accounted for EUR 3 700 billion. And there is also an increasing online consumption. Additional efforts are therefore desperately needed to meet all the challenges. Differences in the level and quality of controls, procedures and penalties are not acceptable. And as one of the largest trading blocs in the world – I conclude, Mr President – we must excel in credibility, efficiency and also a high level of consumer confidence.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, firstly I listened very carefully to what the Commissioner and also the rapporteur, Ms Rozière, said, and I must say that I agree 100%. Obviously, we need to have uniform application, because without it it’s going to be costly for businesses – it can lead to greater fraud, etc. And of course the electronic system needs to be developed to ensure that happens. Indeed, in the broader front, I think in the next mandate in particular, we should put huge emphasis on combating fraud in so many different ways. It should be a priority for the next Commission. I agree also with what has been said about Brexit, but at the same time, one hopes that we will get a deal on Brexit and that it will be an orderly withdrawal, because anything else would be absolutely ridiculous. Finally, I just want to say that we are now talking constantly about completing the customs union, completing the single market and completing the banking union – I look forward to the day when a Commissioner can stand up here and see ‘Hallelujah, we have them completed!’.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, the customs union is, as many have pointed out today, a fundamental basis for the completion of the European common market by common rules — I stress — i stress. This report therefore highlights the challenges of a better functioning of the customs union, particularly at the digital level.  Having said that, however, I will turn to the issue of third countries and insist on the issue of Turkey, addressing you, Commissioner. There are legal obligations of Turkey within the framework of the Customs Union. The obligations are to the European Union and relate in particular to the Republic of Cyprus: normalization of relations with the withdrawal of the occupying army, recognition of the Republic of Cyprus and much more. So I ask you directly in the run-up to the elections: how do you want us to trust you that you are putting forward the common rules of the European Union that we all share, if you are promoting an upgrade of trade relations with Turkey without first meeting its obligations to the European Union?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the development of the Customs Union is an important thing for the European Union itself. However, I would like to raise the issue of customs fraud here. At the moment, we have complaints about illegal imports of alcohol from Bulgaria to Greece, so that the local ouzo and tsipouro industry can no longer function. We have massive illegal imports, so the distillers complain. I've been to areas of Larissa and I've received these complaints.  The second point is that there must be very clear control both at the Greek-Albanian border and at the Greek-Skopje border, because it also makes illegal imports of tsipouro and, of course, Greekizations of products take place: milk imported from Albania appears as Greek. Meat greekizations take place: meats imported from Skopje appear as Greek. These customs frauds must be tackled.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I will be against the tide. I will make a plea for tariffs for a cooperative market because, indeed, from a technical point of view, if you have a single market with a single currency, you have the comparative advantage, and the comparative advantage makes the strong get stronger and stronger, and the weak one gets weaker. Then you have two technical solutions to solve the problem. You have the transfer area solution, the federal budget for the euro area, for example, it is a solution. You have a second solution to balance the internal market and make a cooperative market, which is tariffs. And you have the solution, which is mixed up, to make both a federal transfer budget and to apply tariffs. You have to think about the harmony of the internal market, not just competition and competition.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it has been said here that the customs union has a priority. Yes, the Commissioner began her plea by saying that, of course, the competitiveness of the internal market depends on how the customs union operates, the customs code.  I am rapporteur for the Customs programme and we will have a trialogue on 7 March and I do not want it to be postponed; but if we do not have computerisation, and common rules for checking goods, we cannot talk about competitiveness, but we cannot talk about product safety, we cannot talk about consumer protection, we cannot talk about fair competition in the market and no reduction in corruption, because we need to know that, in customs, there is this corruption in order to pass products that are non-compliant.  That is why, Commissioner, I ask you very much: insist! We have one point to negotiate with the Commission in my report and I will not give in to that. Do you want to be cut off from our budget if Brexit materialises? If we cut from the budget, the customs union will never work.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this important debate.
