As Trade Commissioner, I am more than aware of the importance of a functioning, transparent, smooth and fully trustworthy customs system. It has to be safe. It has to be predictable. It has to be state of the art and very modern. And we are working towards this. This is, of course, very important for the internal market as well. I know that there is frustration about the extension of the transitional period for the full completion of the IT system. We have been fully transparent in this regard by regularly updating and publishing information on the planning schedule for the electronic systems, after consultation with Member States and economic operators. Also, following your request, last year the Commission published a comprehensive report on the state of play of the implementation of the Union Customs Code (UCC). In this report we announced and explained why additional time was needed for the completion of some of the electronic systems. But I do acknowledge that a more strategic report on the progress of the electronic systems and on ways to address any possible delays will further increase transparency. That is why the Commission has undertaken to report to Parliament on the progress regarding the completion of the work on the electronic systems on an annual basis. Concerning Brexit – I think those concerned have left – but as of the withdrawal date the UK will become a third country, as you know, and that implies that the Union Customs Code will apply to trade goods coming from the UK. There are no derogations foreseen and it is the case today. The implementation of the Code falls under Member States’ competence. We understand that they have taken measures with a view to staffing, infrastructure and IT systems necessary after the UK withdrawal. However, of course, withdrawal of the UK without an agreement clearly carries risks and the Commission is in active discussion with Member States on these issues. I would like to thank the rapporteur again and also the other members of the Committee who have helped to highlight the very important issues related to the Customs Union and its functioning. You can be assured that I will convey your comments and suggestions and questions to Commissioner Moscovici.

name: Virginie Rozière
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I again wanted to thank all the colleagues for their participation in the debate, their contributions, their contributions, with one word in particular, of course, for my fellow shadow rapporteurs with whom the work on this report is extremely fruitful. I would also like to thank you, Commissioner, for your answers. I think we are making a largely shared observation, and we also share the paths for improvement to ensure that the customs union, the customs code and all the systems that must contribute to its implementation that are fully dematerialised in the future are developed and that we can meet the new deadlines that we have collectively set. In any case, thank you for your encouraging answers, I hope and I think that the report we have discussed will garner a large majority and that it can provide a common basis for reflection to build a successful customs union together. We need it. Let us remember that this is perhaps too often a little-known and yet fundamental foundation of our European Union.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, 14 February 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The customs union is one of the EU's earliest achievements and is essential to guarantee the credibility and negotiating position of the EU in concluding trade agreements. In practice, the customs union means that the customs authorities of all 28 EU Member States work together as if they were a single body. They apply the same tariffs to goods imported into their territory from abroad and do not apply tariffs in the internal market. The EU's single market would be impossible to achieve without the abolition of customs duties and the role played by the customs union in overseeing imports and exports. Standardisation of information and customs processes plays a key role in harmonising controls, in particular with regard to phenomena such as misclassification and undervaluation of imported goods and misrepresentation of their origin. Such errors are detrimental to all economic operators, and in particular to small and medium-sized enterprises. Customs authorities must strike the required balance between facilitating legitimate trade, customs controls to protect citizens, animals and the environment in Europe, building consumer confidence in goods placed on the internal market and EU trade interests. EU imports and exports amounted to EUR 3 700 billion in 2017 and duties collected accounted for 15% of the EU budget.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the situation in Chechnya and on the case of Ojub Titiyev (2019/2562(RSP)).

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the The director of Memorial in Chechnya has been in prison for a year on a constructed charge. In the show trial of Ojub Titiyev, he faces up to ten years in prison. Our concern is particularly high because his predecessor was murdered by Memorial in Grozny in 2009. This resolution is also a reminder of Natalya Estemirova. Ojub's family is constantly under threat, and his colleagues at Memorial also face ever-increasing persecution, direct violence and criminalization. Memorial is the winner of the European Parliament's Sakharov Prize, and we are convinced by a large majority in this House that we need to take more responsibility for our prizewinners. We therefore call on the European External Action Service – our embassy – to take care of this case. And we call on the Russian authorities to drop the charges and release Ojub Titiyev!

name: Jaromír Štětina
text: Author. – Mr President, being a director of the Memorial branch in Grosch is a dangerous profession. Think of Natalya Estěmirov, titjev's predecessor, who was murdered in 2009. Titjev is awaiting sentencing, which could send him to prison for 10 years or more. Today's Chechen President Kadyrov, established after the Second Chechen War by Putin, has introduced a regime of lawlessness in Chechnya. Under this regime, Titjev and his organization, which we awarded the Sakharov Prize ten years ago, are trying to protect those whose lives are being ruined.  I worked as a journalist for several years in the first and second Chechen wars. I've seen the crimes committed by the 58th Russian army. In the war, it killed 80,000 civilians, destroyed about 200 villages, destroyed three towns, destroyed the country's infrastructure, drove half the Chechen nation into the diaspora. Many of my friends were killed or killed, including Anna Politkovsky, my friend, with whom I worked in the Second War. To this day, kadyrov's regime adores these war crimes. Titjev's memorial movement considers him an enemy.  I am glad that Mr Titjev won last year's Czech President Václav Havel Award, which is awarded by the Council of Europe. Titjev must be unconditionally released.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the There is no doubt that Russia, and in particular the leadership of the Chechen Republic, has a duty to respect fundamental and human rights. They have committed themselves to this, not least through international agreements and UN agreements, especially as a member of the Council of Europe and a signatory to the European Convention on Human Rights. Unfortunately, the fate of Ojub Titiyev, head of the office of the Russian ngo-organisation Memorial in Chechnya, shows a serious violation here and, unfortunately, is obviously only the tip of an iceberg of worrying human rights violations by the Chechen authorities. Our group and I share the joint resolution's approach of finally ending the coordinated attacks on human rights organisations and activists, giving non-governmental organisations appropriate opportunities to investigate human rights violations and, at the same time, guaranteeing and implementing without hindrance all democratic rights legally guaranteed, including the obligations to state and social bodies arising from international agreements, on the basis of applicable Russian Federation law. This includes the immediate release of Ojub Titiyev.

name: Daniele Viotti
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have already dealt with Chechnya too many times in this House, in this Parliament, not least last October, so I agree with all my fellow Members who have written this resolution.  However, I would like to use this minute to recall the memory of Assil Belalta. Assil Belalta was a 21-year-old boy who was killed, cut, in Algeria a few days ago. With his blood, in his college room, it was written "He is gay", as if this were a fault. A 21-year-old boy who was studying medicine, who was in his third year of medicine, was killed in Algeria because he is gay. We must oppose this, and he was killed after two weeks that the President of the Algerian Magistrates had said: 'we will oppose any law against homophobia'.  So Europe must oppose this, we cannot stand up to what is happening in Chechnya, we cannot stand what is happening in Algeria, we cannot yet see homosexual victims from regimes that are dictatorial. We can't let that be allowed anymore. The hands of Algerian politicians and the Algerian media are dirty with Assil's blood.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: author. – Mr President, the Chechen director of Sakharov prize—winning Memorial, Oyub Titiev, has been in prison for over a year now on trumped—up charges, and we expect a verdict any day now. The risk that human rights defenders in Chechnya are taking is illustrated by the fact that Titiev’s predecessor, Natalya Estemirova, was brutally murdered, and others face constant threats and intimidation.  So today we call for the release of Oyub Titiev and the dropping of charges, and we urge the Chechen authorities to respect their own laws and constitution and at least every citizen’s human and legal rights. The harassment of NGOs and journalists really has to stop, but we also need to hold to account the perpetrators of the worst human rights violations through a European ‘Magnitsky Act’. It is urgent. I call on celebrities who think it is fancy to take money from a dictator to perform or to be present to stop doing that and to consider the money they make that way dirty money.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, it is now over a year since Oyub Titiev was arrested on trumped—up drug charges, clearly targeted in response to his continued actions in documenting and exposing human rights abuses in Chechnya. The Russian federal authorities have so far failed to investigate the extrajudicial killing of 27 men two years ago, and Titiev, Head of the Chechen Memorial Office remains in pre-trial detention a year after his arrest. Russia has international commitments to protect human rights defenders, and they should take heed of the OSCE report that calls for Mr Titiev’s trial to be moved out of Chechnya and for him to be released immediately. It’s also time for the ICC to carry out meaningful investigations into the alleged crimes against humanity during the second Chechen war. These persistent human rights abuses under the watch of President Kadyrov cannot be allowed to continue unchecked. It is a disgrace.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, my political group has fought hard for a resolution on the case of Oyoub Titiev, since this eminent human rights defender has been behind bars for more than 13 months on the basis of clearly fabricated charges. His trial, which cannot be described as anything other than ridiculous, is coming to an end. So now is the time to make our voices heard more than ever. If Oyoub Titiev is in prison today, it is only because he refused to bow down to Mr. Kadyrov and continued to report human rights violations in the region. With this case, invented from scratch, Mr. Kadyrov's goal is to silence the latter voice critical of his regime. I remind you that Memorial is the last non-governmental organization operating in Chechnya, the Chechen leader has indeed made sure to expel them one by one. In addition, we have all heard at the end of last year that the region will soon be a territory forbidden to human rights defenders, which it places in the same category as terrorists and extremists. So I believe that the time has come for Mr Putin to save his honour and to use the little influence he still has in Chechnya to free Mr Titiev.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, today we demand the immediate dismissal of the director of the Chechen office of the human rights organisation Memoriál Ojub Titjev, who is, among other things, the winner of the Václav Havel Prize and is detained on the basis of fabricated evidence. But it can't end with his release. The European Union must adopt the European equivalent of the Magnitsky Act. None of those responsible for human rights violations in Russia and Chechnya may be entitled to an entry visa or the possibility of obtaining property within the EU. It is clear that neither the Russian nor the Chechen authorities are willing to respect human rights on their territory, nor are they committed to them. Russia's membership of the Council of Europe in this sense is rather ridiculous.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, after years of harassment and intimidation, Oyub Titiev, the director of the Memorial Human Rights Centre and the 2018 Vaclav Havel Human Rights Prize winner, was illegally arrested on 9 January 2018 on fabricated drug charges. A week later, Memorial’s office in Ingushetia was set on fire. Two months ago, Shali City Court prolonged – without any justification – his pre—trial detention until 22 March 2019. He may face up to 10 years in prison. Memorial – 2009 Sakharov Prize winner – is the last independent non—governmental organisation operating in Chechnya and Titiev’s arbitrary detention is clearly politically motivated and a retaliation for his courage to document the kidnappings, torture, illegal arrests and killings in one of the most repressive regions in Europe. Like we did one year ago, we must call on the authorities of the Chechen Republic of the Russian Federation to immediately and unconditionally release Oyub Titiev, and also address the situation of human rights defenders, including the massive persecution and extrajudicial killing of LGBTI people.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ten years ago Natalya Estemirova was brutally murdered in Chechnya for her work on human rights. Since then, sadly, the atmosphere for activists and journalists in Chechnya has not improved. Oyub Titiev, her successor as director of the Human Rights NGO Memorial, not only faces ten years in prison on charges that that are widely recognised as fabricated, but has in recent months seen his colleagues, lawyer, personal life and even family threatened. The arrest of Mr Titiev falls in a clear pattern in which the authorities of the Chechen Republic tried to crush all criticism of Ramzan Kadyrov, the Kremlin—backed leader of Chechnya.  Therefore, I urge the Council to continue its work on a Magnitsky Act, the High Representative as well as the European External Action Service (EEAS) to give this and all other cases of political persecution a priority in EU—Russia discussions, and my colleagues to put this incredible injustice on their countries’ agendas.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I, too, would like to stress that mr Kadyrov's regime has been created in Chechnya, which is a regime of lawlessness, where there is no right at all, where, on the contrary, the state protects those who break the law and those it should protect, various minorities, actively persecutes them. This regime, above it, holds the protective hand of Russia. I think that this should also be heard here, and I join the call of all of you who are calling for the release of Mr Titjev, who is being held completely unlawfully and holds both the Václav Havel and Sakharov Prizes.  I would like to stress that recently – and it is not just a matter of one year – the European Court of Human Rights has begun to strongly condemn Russia for violations of the rights of Chechens and violations of rights on Chechen territory. I think that we should think about how to make these judgments more enforceable in the European area, because it cannot just be a question of money that is obtained by those whose rights have been violated in this way.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in Chechnya, that is, in that part of the Russian Federation, persecution is being done against human rights activists and the media , who are trying to report freely and, on many occasions, unsuccessfully, by the intolerable attitudes of the Chechen regional and Russian national governments. Oyub Titiev's case is bleeding: an illegal process was fabricating him by the Chechen authorities that has put him in jail, as we all know, with false accusations. The European Union, and also the European Parliament, cannot look the other way and we must call for the immediate release of Oyub Titiev. And the European institutions must also address the Russian authorities to protest these illegal detentions and the lack of fair trials, as well as the human rights violation that is taking place in that territory.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, again we stand here discussing the situation in Chechnya, the situation for LGBTI persons and, of course, especially today, the situation of human rights defender Mr Oyub Titiev. Human rights organisations and media reported in December and January on a new wave of detention and torture by Chechen law enforcement officials affecting at least 40 LGBTI people. At least two detained people are reported to have died. These are very grave violations of human rights, adding to a long list of abuses in Chechnya and we reacted again strongly to the situation of LGBTI people there, as we did earlier.  A report by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe sets out clear evidence of successive purges against LGBTI people in Chechnya, as well as many other human rights violations. It is essential that Russian authorities address the recommendations of the report and take steps to implement them, including investigations of the role of the Chechen authorities. As part of an alarming trend of attacks on human rights defenders and journalists in Chechnya, a court in Chechnya confirmed, as you have said, last June the detention of Oyub Titiev, head of the regional office of the very respected NGO Memorial human rights centre. He has now been detained for over a year on questionable drug possession charges. The arrest appears to be directly connected to his human rights work. Memorial has been the subject of ongoing intimidation and harassment in the North Caucasus. Mr Titiev should be immediately released.  We recall the duty of the Russian Federation to protect all its citizens, ensure the safety of all persons at risk owing to sexual orientation and order the Chechen leadership accordingly. We expect full and transparent investigation into the report and persecution, torture and killings of LGBTI people in Chechnya. Anyone found responsible or complicit in such hate crimes should be brought to justice. It is also the duty of the Russian Federation to respect and protect the legal rights of human rights defenders, including Oyub Titiev, in line with Russia’s international human rights commitments.  We remain committed to combating all forms of discrimination and hate crime, strongly supporting the rights of all LGBTI persons as well as human rights defenders in general, and of course Mr Oyub Titiev in particular. The EU has consistently called upon Russia, and will continue to do so, to ensure that human rights violations in Chechnya are investigated and justice for victims ensured. Thank you very much for putting this important issue on the agenda.  (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Zimbabwe (2019/2563 (RSP).

name: Geoffrey Van Orden
text: author. – Mr President, today, as Chairman of the Friends of Zimbabwe, I want to appeal directly to President Mnangagwa of Zimbabwe.  President, six months ago, when you took office, you promised change and a bright, shared future for all Zimbabweans, with a government unwavering in its commitment to the rule of law, with policies that would project harmony and stability and attract foreign investment. I urge you to get back on that right road, to break clean from the evil forces lurking in your shadow, to dismiss those responsible for the recent brutalities, to release all the political prisoners and work with the opposition forces, the churches and civil society in a great national dialogue that will lead to the genuine and sustainable democratic change that your people so desperately want. Do this and I feel sure the international community stands ready to give you every assistance. Do the right thing and history will judge you well.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Van Orden. As an explanation, it is usually in this format that the floor is given in this format, not according to the strength of the group, but after the motion for a resolution has been tabled. That is why Mrs Sargentini is now following suit.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Author. Mr President, in November 2017, President Mnangagwa came to power with a coup. In the summer of 2018 there were elections in Zimbabwe. In the six months that he had not yet been officially elected, we had a chance to force concessions from the country, and we failed to do so. And what have we seen now, January 2019. The Mnangagwa government has cracked down on the opposition and it seems that Mugabe's times have come back. NgOs, opposition members are threatened, are being taken from their homes. People are locked up, without it being clear why. The population is being beaten down with severe violence. And what's our response? The question for the Commissioner is what we can do to improve the situation here.

name: Aleksander Gabelic
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by thanking all those involved in the drafting of this resolution. The situation in Zimbabwe is acute and it is very important that it is brought to the attention and that we here in the European Parliament clearly mark against the development that has been in the country since 14 January. We must clearly point out against the use of violence and harassment against citizens and trade unionists who choose to peacefully protest against the sharp price increases that have hit the country. All political prisoners must be released immediately and we must clearly mark against widespread sexual violence. People who have been affected must have immediate access to medical assistance. I had hoped that the resolution had taken a clearer stand for the affected trade union leaders Peter Mutasa and Japhet Moyo and the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions as a whole, but I am pleased that this resolution has broad support in Parliament and that it is a clear support for the people of Zimbabwe, who have suffered for a long time, for human rights and for peaceful and democratic development.

name: Catherine Bearder
text: author. – Mr President, after years of authoritarian rule, hopes rose with the election of a new president. But that has quickly evaporated, plunging the country into crisis. With runaway inflation, the final insult of high fuel prices was the final straw. Anger and anxiety has pushed protesters onto the streets and their government's response – a legal crackdown on dissenting voices; arrests, use of force, live ammunition, door-to-door searches, intimidation and harassment, Internet scrambling, you name it! Zimbabweans and their human rights defenders have the courage to stand up to their government and we need to stand with them. Fleeing Zimbabweans must get the assistance they need in neighbouring countries to comply with international law and to the UK I say, stop returning Zimbabweans until it's proved to be safe.  We must encourage a peaceful, democratic, national dialogue on an equal footing with civil society, religious leaders, opposition and government, to find a better solution for Zimbabwe – a sustainable solution that ends this violence once and for all.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, the departure of Robert Mugabe in November 2017, after 37 years of dictatorship, had raised immense hope. Unfortunately, the election of Emmerson Mnangagwa was immediately contested and resulted in violence, resulting in several deaths. Despite the electoral commission of inquiry and the new president's promises, tensions fuelled by the economic collapse have continued to grow. The 150% increase in the price of fuel, when it is already one of the most expensive in the world, has had the effect of a spark. Protests after the 14 January strike were brutally suppressed. Riot police fired live ammunition. Deaths, torture, beatings, at least a thousand arrests according to the police itself and a judicial machine running at full speed: all means are used to silence the protest. There is an urgent need to act, there is an urgent need to help with political dialogue, the European Union and the African Union must help, rather than turning a blind eye as in Mugabe's time.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, change everything so as not to change anything. This is a summary of the delicate scenario that has opened up in Zimbabwe after 37 years of Robert Mugabe's dictatorship. It would seem impossible to imagine a worsening of the situation after forty years of tyranny, hunger and bloodshed, but President Mnangagwa is laying the foundations for success in the very difficult task.  Mugabe's former vice-president, Mnangagwa, known as 'the crocodile', has been associated with some of the worst atrocities since independence, and today his security forces have returned to get their hands dirty with 17 dead, 343 seriously injured and several cases of torture and rape. Meanwhile, the opposition is being decimated: thousands of demonstrators have been imprisoned, including nine-year-olds, and also sum-up tried. Many others remain detained without trial.  I wonder what has really changed in Zimbabwe. What has certainly remained the same is contempt for human rights and the annihilation of opposition. That is why we must call on the African Union to include the Zimbabwe crisis as a priority at the next regular session of its Executive Council.

name: Elmar Brok
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The current president was Mugabe's deputy and is partly responsible for all the actions of Mugabe's time. After the fall of Mugabe, however, we believed we had a chance of a change. This has been communicated to the government – and, quite clearly, to Mrs Sargentini – that if you now follow sensible procedures and hold free elections, we can open up the opening that you need economically. Realising that he could lose the elections, he fell back into the old pre-election methods and got the opposition into trouble, which did not really make free elections possible, as the European Union's election observers have noted. The day after – I myself was in the demonstrations – he then attacked peaceful demonstrators with the army and shot a few people. And that has continued. The opposition's computers were taken over so that they could not prove that there had been electoral fraud. And this is now continuing in the old way. Firstly, we should make it clear – as the European Union has said – that things must be put right and that we, as the European Union, can only provide support if it is democracy ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Eduard Kukan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Zimbabwe is facing a deepening crisis in every aspect. In these trying times, the Government must show leadership and willingness to tackle the difficult economic situation without excessive use of force and within a framework of rule of law. The new leadership in Zimbabwe has a duty to uphold the fundamental rights of its citizens, which includes freedom of assembly, association and expression, and to protect citizens from arbitrary detention. Disproportionate and excessive use of force against civilians is unacceptable. Abuses by security forces must end. President Mnangagwa’s Government should pay attention to the Human Rights Commission in its report. That is why the EU also needs to stand ready to assist the country effectively in the reform process, which is a matter of urgency.

name: Neena Gill
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, a year ago, there was real optimism that the repression of previous decades was over. Unfortunately, as an observer during Zimbabwe’s last presidential election, I witnessed post-election violence which put an end to those hopes with recent government crackdowns – we’ve already heard – on anti-government protesters, including trade union leaders and opposition. The promises of a peaceful, prosperous, democratic Zimbabwe made during those elections – it really has to be understood – are a prerequisite for international support, for debt relief, for economic recovery. They really do need to be delivered on.  Our condemnation so far has fallen on deaf ears and, unfortunately, facing internal power struggle, key actors find it easier to blame outsiders for the political and economic crisis they’re in, as opposed to taking responsibility. But for the European Union, given Russia and China’s growing influence, I think it’s important we have a clear strategy. How are we going to support dialogue between different stakeholders in the country?

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as Nelson Chamisa, the leader of the opposition, says, a year and a half after Mugabe left power, the escalation of repression against opponents makes Mugabe almost look like a dragonfly in terms of terrorism, domestic terrorism against opponents.  From neighbouring South Africa, where 130 000 people have fled in one day alone since mid-January, some have reported a serious humanitarian crisis, even calling for the intervention of the International Criminal Court. The question arises as to why such a request is not also made by the territory of the European Union. It is time, just think of the long tradition of heinous murders that have taken place against our fellow countrymen, farmers of European origin. And perhaps even the very serious economic and humanitarian crisis has its distant origins in that period, which was not really of great honour to European civilisation and to the role of defending European citizens. We are asking for the financing of EUR 234 million for the period...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as demonstrators filled the streets of Harare last January to protest against the dramatic increase of fuel prices and runaway inflation, President Mnangagwa reacted with the same authority, reflecting thus his autocratic predecessor Robert Mugabe, deploying soldiers and security forces to crack down on demonstrators, resulting in numerous arrests, the deaths of at least a dozen unarmed civilians and the shutting down of the internet. President Mnangagwa, who was elected on a promise to stabilise the economy and allow greater democratic freedom, is betraying his promises to create a new Zimbabwe and address the political and economic challenges in the country.  The EU, besides condemning the excessive violence and intimidation by the Zimbabwean authorities and calling for the immediate release of all detainees, must extend the individual financial and travel restrictions to those associated with these human rights infringements, and support an inclusive national dialogue that can produce a roadmap to genuine economic, political and electoral reforms.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the situation in Zimbabwe is explosive: demonstrations, murders, arrests, the rule of law is not respected, the Internet has been shut down and the new President continues mugabe policy, that is to say an authoritarian policy, a clearly undemocratic policy with imprisonment and a restriction of democratic rights. At the same time, the price of fuel has increased by 130%, people are protesting and there are thousands of refugees leaving the country. I therefore believe that the European Union must send a decisive signal to the President of Zimbabwe. First of all, to put an end to funding: the European Union's aid to Zimbabwe amounts to EUR 234 million. It must also call for the intervention of the Union of African States.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, aontaím leis an údar, an Feisire Van Orden, i ngach rud a dúirt sé faoin ábhar seo. Gan dabht ar bith, táimid ag féachaint ar fhear a chuaigh ar aghaidh don toghchán agus a gheall go ndéanfadh sé gach rud a chabhródh leis na daoine dá dtoghfaí é. Ach ansin, nuair a toghadh é, chuaigh sé siar ar a ghealltanais. Dar ndóigh, chuaigh daoine i mbun agóide, agus cad a rinne sé? Chuir sé na fórsaí amach ag lámhach agus ag marú daoine agus ag caitheamh daoine óga, daoine idir 9 mbliana agus sé bliana déag, i bpríosún agus dhún sé síos an t-idirlíon.  Dá bhrí sin, tá sé ceart go mbeadh díospóireacht againn ar maidin faoi seo agus go gcuirfeadh an tAontas, tríd an gCoimisinéir, gach brú is féidir ar údaráis na Siombáibe chun é seo a chur ina cheart.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to this debate and I join the arguments of my colleagues. The current situation in Zimbabwe is a great disappointment, it is a disappointing hope that we have put in the presidential elections. The situation does not change, it is the same as under Mugabe, on the contrary, even worse. If someone is using the power tools of the state – the army, the police – against citizens, demonstrators who are protesting against a dismal economic situation, closing people down, abusing people for expressing their views on the situation in the country, then we must condemn it.  I'm afraid he'll probably stay with the judgment. It is up to the Commission, Commissioner, if we can do more, if we can put more pressure on the regime in Zimbabwe with economic instruments, to treat its citizens a little more dignifiedly and a little more appropriately. I personally would recommend it, otherwise in six months to a year we can talk about Zimbabwe here in the same fashion, in the same situation as now. So I recommend tougher action by the Commission.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Zimbabwe has lived for forty years, almost forty years, under Mugabe's dictatorship, and the population has had to suffer from poverty, inflation, violence, repression. More than three million citizens have left - most in South Africa - almost a quarter of the population. Unfortunately, even during President Mnangagwa, things are no better: they strike in opposition with brutality, in protesters who have come out because of rising fuel prices and poverty. We have nearly 37 dead, we have over 600 victims of violence, torture, over a thousand arrests. The European Union must strongly demand that the current President and the current government withdraw the army as a matter of urgency, not to use violence. There must be a real dialogue between power and opposition, which can possibly be mediated by a neutral side, and obviously we must strongly demand that fundamental human rights be respected.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Mugabe regime seems to have come to an end. The hopes raised by last year's events came with a cold shower. We see the same practices, we see the suppression of legitimate protests, we see the dead, arrests, even arrests of children. The hope that was raised last year is really extinguishing, and we should ask, and I agree with my previous sayings: What can we do for the people of this state? We can, of course, demand dismissal, but we must combine the instruments at our disposal. Firstly, the economic ones mentioned here by my colleague Pospisil, and secondly, the diplomatic ones. We must ask for support from the African Union. By combining these instruments, I think we can achieve the effects that we want, and that is therefore a free people in the democratic country of Zimbabwe.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for focusing attention again on Zimbabwe and the very difficult situation there at this critical moment. Unfortunately our assessment is, as you all say, that the recent development in Zimbabwe is a serious setback. Following the increase in fuel prices by over 150%, a decision which of course triggered violent protests in an already tense political environment, the repression by security forces against demonstrators, trade unions, NGOs, opposition supporters, has been unacceptable.  On 17 January the EU strongly condemned this crackdown, which has resulted in many casualties, widespread human rights violations – including reports of sexual violence – and hundreds of arbitrary arrests. We have a responsibility to Zimbabweans to express ourselves in these circumstances. Our Head of Delegation in Harare met high-level representatives of the Government, including the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Home Affairs and Justice to express our deep concerns and to urge the authorities to behave in full compliance with its constitutional obligations. In Brussels, the EEAS convened a meeting with the Ambassador of Zimbabwe in the same context. In times of economic hardship, demonstrations are to be expected. Human rights and the rule of law, as enshrined in the constitution of Zimbabwe, should be upheld. Vandalism and lootings by rioters is of course to be condemned but security forces must respond in a proportionate and professional manner and they have to be accountable to citizens for their actions. These tragic developments underline the urgent need to address the findings and recommendations of the commission of inquiry that was set up by the President himself in response to last August’s post-election violence. Security sector reform is also a priority and the government should ensure that security-related laws are aligned swiftly with the Constitution. The Government will not be able to implement reforms that stand the test of time without an environment that ensures an inclusive national dialogue through which citizens can exercise their freedoms of assembly, association and expression. The events that led to the resignation of President Mugabe and to the entry into office of a new leadership, raised, as you have said, high expectations. We decided to engage with the new Zimbabwe knowing that change would not and cannot come overnight after decades of the Mugabe regime. But this being said, the recent crackdown sadly cast serious doubt over the declared determination of the Government to engage in political and economic reforms. We cannot, and should not, ignore the dire economic and social situation of the people of Zimbabwe and I pay tribute to the attention given by the different political groups in this House in this regard. I would like to underline that the EUR 234 million that has been given to Zimbabwe under the last long-term budget has achieved positive results. It does not go to the Government but is invested in the health system, in agricultural production and in food security. But any strengthening of our relations with Zimbabwe can only occur on the basis of clear and concrete evidence that the Government is truly committed to reforms that lead the country towards a democratic and prosperous future, and this message was also conveyed by Commissioner Mimica in his last meeting with President Mnangagwa last week in Addis.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I supported Parliament's resolution on the human rights situation in Zimbabwe. I always try to emphasise the essential function of the state: to ensure a healthy environment for the development and prosperity of our people. It is therefore very important to me that human rights are guaranteed, respected and protected, both in Zimbabwe and in all other countries of Africa and the world. Everyone is guaranteed the right to education, education, employment, decent wages and full-fledged living in old age. Public authorities must take care of the welfare of the population, the public. The current level of crime, the incapacity of police authorities contribute to the inciting chaos and illegal acts. Violence, repression or constant aggression must not remain in the state. This requires not only internal reforms. Dialogue with the rest of the world and the sharing of experience on crime prevention are needed. Separately, I emphasise the protection and enforcement of the rights of women and children. The country should develop a medium conducive to the prosperity of families.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on women's rights activists in Saudi Arabia (2019/2564 (RSP)).

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman has been keen to market himself as a progressive visionary since coming to power: ushering in headline-grabbing reforms, such as removing the ban on women driving, and allowing cinemas to operate freely in the country. On other fundamental issues, however, we see little changing, particularly for women as they continue to be subject to the harsh guardianship laws imposed by the Saudi authorities. These laws and the repressive culture surrounding them are making the everyday lives of Saudi women unbearable. These measures are often defended by the authorities as being rooted in Wahhabi religious norms, yet when we look at neighbouring countries in the Gulf, such as the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait and Bahrain, it’s plain for all to see that the laws in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia are significantly more restrictive. I’d also like to take the opportunity to raise again the case of Jamal Khashoggi. The investigation into the torture and murder of Mr Khashoggi at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul remains inconclusive, and I continue to be deeply concerned about the many reports which allege links at the highest levels of the Saudi state.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: Author. – Mr President, I have to say that it sometimes becomes unbearable the double measuring stick we have in relation to our external action. We currently have relations, and many Member States have relations with what is a genuine theocracy, which has an institutionalised system of discrimination against women and which, above all, detains its activists and maintains a system of male protection towards them that is absolutely incompatible with any democratic value. And that is why I believe that this Parliament and the European External Action Service need to be much more forceful in denouncing human rights violations in Saudi Arabia. We want a clear pronouncement in defense of the activists. That their release be called for, that torture ceases, that sexual abuse cease when they are arrested and also, more globally, in relation to our relations with Saudi Arabia, we must demand that countries comply with the arms export code of conduct and that they cease our arms trade relations with Saudi Arabia at once. It is therefore urgent to rethink our external relations with what is a real theocracy.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over and above bin Salman's attempts to present the face of a Saudi Arabia to the world on the road to reform, the reality goes the other way, and once again we must denounce the serious human rights situation.  Two cases give cause for concern. The first is the news of the torture suffered in prison by women's rights activists, who have been detained since May 2018. The second concerns the progress of the trial of Israa Al-Ghomgham, her husband, and four other activists arrested in 2015 for taking part in a peaceful protest in support of the Shiite minority. The latter are tried before the Specialised Criminal Court, designed for terrorist offences, as is likely to be the case for some activists arrested in May 2018. We are calling for liberation, we are calling for basically all these people to be released. We have also requested, at the same time, in the resolution, that a delegation from the European Parliament, consisting of the Subcommittee on Human Rights and the Committee on Women's Rights, should be allowed to go to Saudi Arabia. Finally, we call on the Commission to get out of a kind of hibernation, in which it seems to have swooped into relations with Riyadh, and to act with greater strength and determination, so that human rights begin to assert themselves in that country.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the most misogynistic and obscurantist country in the world continues to make people talk about themselves. A country where hatred, intolerance and discrimination continue to lead the hand and tarnish the minds of those in power.  To do the trick again to a medieval society, the generous and avant-garde Prince bin Salman allowed women to drive and participate in sporting events, as if the problems of this country were driving and football. The end of the driving ban was unfortunately a Pyrrhic victory for women activists, given the dozens of cases of alleged torture in detention, sexual abuse, assault, sleep deprivation and legal aid. The courageous activism of these women against an establishment that regards them as animals is barbarically punished and repressed, because if nothing counts you cannot ask for anything.  That is why I continue to ask you how a champion country of human rights violations such as Saudi Arabia can occupy a place on the Human Rights Council. Its stay in the Council is totally incompatible and intrinsically contradictory to the values and mission of this body and must be suspended immediately.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, in June 2018, women were finally granted the right to drive in Saudi Arabia. Huge victory? No, "measure." Saudi Arabia fell from 138th to 141st out of 144 in the world ranking on the gender gap. Women are under the tutelage of men; for the slightest act of their daily lives, they are considered inferior, victims of countless violence. Worse, an application put online by the Saudi government, Absher (the preacher), accessible via Google and Apple, allows the husband to control his wife, especially if it comes to him to try exile alone, as is the case of a thousand Saudi women, every year. In fact, the men and women we are talking about today, all women's rights activists, are symbols. Arrested at the time of the introduction of a driver's licence, tortured, whipped, electrocuted, and facing very long prison sentences. So let us not be fooled by the so-called progressive agenda of MbS (Mohammad bin Salman Al Saud), no more at home than in Yemen, finally act.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: author. – Mr President, all the promises of reform that came with the appointment of Mohammed bin Salman and his lofty vision 2030, and that were met with much wishful thinking all around the world, have been definitively crushed by actions such as the systematic violations of women’s rights and human rights and by the lack of basic freedoms that people face. Women are effectively second-class citizens in Saudi Arabia, and that is unacceptable. More specifically, now, the arrests and torture of the brave women’s rights activists – and we name all of them in this resolution – are absolutely appalling. Their families are being intimidated and are facing travel restrictions because their passports have been revoked. This is absolutely appalling. We need to condemn, at the highest European level, these actions by Mohammed bin Salman and all the Saudi authorities involved. More importantly, however, these actions and the violations of human rights in Saudi Arabia have to have consequences. We need a European Magnitsky Act to hold perpetrators of human-rights violations to account individually, and we need to stop the export of the very surveillance technologies, built in Europe, which are used for repression in countries like Saudi Arabia. It is high time that we responded, in our treatment of Saudi Arabia, not to the beautiful words that they say, but to the ugly deeds that must have consequences.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: Author. – Mr President, many women and men are currently in prison in Saudi Arabia simply because they are defending gender equality. Women in Saudi Arabia, for example, still have to have male guardians, without whose consent they cannot apply for employment or higher education. It is unacceptable to us that women should still be inferior at this time. To some extent, this can be seen as a culturally conditioned matter, but with all due respect for culture and religion, we cannot close our eyes to examples of clear human rights violations and trampling on human dignity.  As a Christian, I am very concerned that in Saudi Arabia Christians are also second-order citizens and cannot practice their faith, otherwise they are intimidated. Our report gives some examples of positive developments, e.g. the possibility for women to drive, to obtain a driving licence. But it's all at the cost of great suffering and imprisonment.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, equality between men and women is one of the basic pillars of the European Union. But even in the European Union we haven’t full equality as we often have debates here, for instance, last month in relation to getting more women on boards. Also in relation to pay, there isn’t full equality, but at least we are working towards it: far different to what happens in many third countries, where, as Marietje Schaake said, women are treated as second-class citizens, and this is obviously not good enough, and Saudi Arabia is one example.  While they have made some progress in relation to allowing women to drive cars – big deal – they are far from being prepared to give equality. Especially, putting women’s rights defenders into jail and torturing them is just not good enough, and we have to raise our voices until we actually see equality between men and women all around the globe.

name: Soraya Post
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, to the Saudi authorities: shame on you. You arrest and torture women just because they defend their human rights. How come you don’t look at women as human beings? We women across the world request that you release these women immediately. The male guardianship system has to be abolished and all forms of gender-based violence, including genital mutilation, marital rape, sexual assault and harassment, has to be criminalised. Stop this cruelty to human beings. We look forward to positive changes and actions. We know that you can do better.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Saudi Arabia, which is a preferential partner for many Member States, is sadly known for being one of the countries where repression against human rights defenders is fierce, imprisoning and executing its activists. They try to offer us a modern image and remain anchored in a feudal, sexist and misogina structure, marked by the legal protection of men over women in all areas. That is why we call on the Saudi authorities to end their campaign of terror and release all imprisoned human rights defenders and ratify all international human rights instruments. You, who demand so much from some countries, are never heard of demanding the same for Saudi Arabia. Finally, to ask the Council to respect the Common Position and to have all Member States carry out an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia immediately. I would remind you, Commissioner, that the Commission itself has put Saudi Arabia on the list of countries at risk of financing terrorism and funding laundering.

name: Jill Seymour
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, we are all too aware of the atrocious treatment of women in Saudi Arabia. I will say that there have been some token relaxations of their situation, such as the right to drive, but women are still second—class citizens, deprived of even the most basic control of their lives. This is completely and utterly unacceptable. There have even been reports of right—to—drive activists being tortured.  It is an absolute travesty that we have to stand here, in the 21st century, discussing such medieval treatment of women and the denial of their basic rights. If the Saudi Government wishes to have a good working relationship with the Western countries, including the UK, then they need to treat women by the internationally recognised standards.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This is not the first time that the human rights situation in Saudi Arabia has concern us. We should deal with it more often, and there needs to be clear signals towards Riyadh. The Saudis' constant assertions that they are willing to submit to modern standards are worth nothing if they do not withstand a reality check. Much does not correspond to official tinkering, not only the murder of Jamal Khashoggi, which speaks to all civilisational norms, or the regularly celebrated public executions or the use of physical force as a means of punishment, or the still unfinished detention of our Sakharov Prize winner Raif Badawi. Systematic contempt for human rights for women is the breeding ground on which such thinking can develop in the first place. If we want to change something in the long term, we must start with this. As long as women are regarded as second-tier human beings, placed under male guardianship and subjected to physical violence, there will be no awareness of human rights. The many women who rebel against this state of affairs in Saudi Arabia deserve all our support.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the world cannot continue to ignore what is happening in Saudi Arabia. The regime of Mohammad Bin Salman arrests Raif Badawi, laureate Sakharov, activists such as Loujain al-Hathloul kidnapped in the Emirates. It is the regime of oppressive guardians of women, which quarterly critics such as Jamal Khashoggi, oppresses the people in the country and neighboring countries like Bahrain, provokes in Syria, Iraq and Iran, conducts an extermination war in Yemen and promotes extremist proselytizing in the world. It is unacceptable that the Member States of the European Union do not yet apply an arms embargo in accordance with the common position. It is a criminal for European politicians and organisations to be bought by the Saudi regime, including in this Parliament and even in the College of Europe. Targeted sanctions, including asset freezes, are indispensable against the heads of this regime. Governments, banks and obliged entities are now under intense scrutiny to implement the European Commission's decision to include Saudi Arabia on the list of high-risk third countries in money laundering and terrorist financing. The courageous women, who fight for human rights in Saudi Arabia, theirs and everyone else's, and to get the country out of this dictatorship... (The President withdraws his floor to the speaker)

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am very happy for the debate that is taking place here, because it is really absurd what is happening in Saudi Arabia in relation to activists who are fighting for women's rights. It has yet to be said in the debate that there is a serious suspicion that these activists are being locked up illegally because they fought for women's rights to drive. Surely the listeners watching this performance today will find it completely absurd that, until recently, women could not drive motor vehicles in Saudi Arabia, and those who fought for this completely banal right of women were thus imprisoned, abused and unlawfully punished.  So I call on the Commissioner, it really is so shameful that we must do our utmost here to radically speak out against Saudi Arabia through all economic and other interests, in short, it is simply not possible to regard as an EU partner a country that denies the banal, fundamental human rights of women.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it has now become absolutely clear that women are the subject of terrible violence in Saudi Arabia. The last case, the one that aroused the interest of the world, was precisely the terrible treatment that was given to activists who demonstrated for fundamental basic rights, such as the right to drive. These women have been tortured, colleagues, with electroshocks, have been sexually harassed, they have been subjected to terrible torture.  So this is totally unacceptable. And it is not enough, as I say to the Commissioner, for a joint motion for a resolution, which is also necessary. We need much stronger and much stronger steps, such as immediately lifting the arms embargo on this country which does not respect the rights of human beings in the slightest.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the repression of human rights in Saudi Arabia is, unfortunately, a sad reality, and it is women who are most oppressed. Until a while ago, they couldn't even drive a car. And, of course, those — and especially women — who resist and fight for women's rights are treated harshly by the Saudi regime, where the death penalty is even carried out. A regime that slaughters civilians in Yemen, a regime that funds terrorism. I think it is time to take concrete action against Saudi Arabia and impose an arms embargo, because that is the only way they can understand that the European Union has a strong voice on this issue and they will be forced and forced to respect and respect women's rights and human rights in Saudi Arabia in general.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this Parliament cannot keep on ignoring the harsh reality that women in Saudi Arabia face in their daily life to promote equal rights. Since May 2018, the authorities in Saudi Arabia have arrested more than a dozen women activists without charge and kept most of them in prison without any hope of release. Just last week, at the EU—League of Arab States Summit in Brussels, Saudi Arabia committed itself to a more progressive agenda on gender equality, but its actions show quite the opposite. Israa al-Ghomgham is the first woman to be sentenced to death simply for participating in protests. Exposed to gender-based violence and for challenging traditional notions of family and gender roles in society, women like Israa, are being, as we speak, treated by the Saudi authorities as agents of embassies and therefore dealt with as a real threat to religion, honour and culture, which implies undeserved punishment. Madam Commissioner, we cannot turn a blind eye to the reality in Saudi Arabia. We must condemn these arbitrary trials and urge the Saudi authorities to immediately release these activists. Europe must take a clear stand against this repression and act accordingly.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, there is a saying, and I think it is very true: 'You can tell a tree by fruit'. Crown Prince bin Salman tried to raise some hopes, the appearance that the tree was green and would bear good fruit. And what do we see instead? What is the real fruit of reforms in Saudi Arabia? We see murder, arrests, intolerance, discrimination, arrests of activists even for advocating for women to drive. And freedom of expression is essentially zero.  I think that such a state cannot be a respected, credible partner of the EU. We have certain values that we must protect, and we cannot pretend that a state that is unable to respect fundamental democratic rights is looking like our trusted partner. This is not a tree that bears good fruit.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, human rights represent an important aspect of the EU’s engagement with Saudi Arabia and we regularly address this as part of our comprehensive dialogue with the Saudi Government. The situation of human right defenders, a longstanding priority, including the situation of women rights activists, is central in this endeavour. Since last May, the EU has been engaging with the Saudi authorities raising our concerns and seeking clarification on the circumstances surrounding the arrests of human rights defenders in Saudi Arabia. We have also inquired about torture allegations of activists.  In a constructive approach, we have encouraged Saudi Arabia to extend an invitation to the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights defenders to visit that country. Unfortunately, apart from the notice of the opening of an investigation by the Bureau of the Saudi Public Prosecutor and by the Saudi Human Rights Commission on the allegation of mistreatment of the detained women, reported by international press, there has not been any enlightenment as to the specific criminal charges they are facing. This is a source of increasing disquiet at EU level. I would like to recall that in all our efforts to reach out towards the Saudi authorities we have always reiterated the relevance of the work of human rights defenders and civil society groups in relation to the process of reform which Saudi Arabia is pursuing. We’ve also repeatedly stressed the importance of respecting due process for the individuals arrested. A successful implementation of Saudi Arabia’s Vision 2030, the cornerstone of Saudi reforms, holds an important role for women. Their greater empowerment would bring enormous benefits socially and economically. We will continue in the European Union to follow with grave concern several other cases of activists allegedly facing the risk of imminent execution on charges related to the exercise of fundamental rights and freedoms, including freedom of association, of speech and of religion. Also, as some of you said, the European Union has in the Khashoggi case still a lot of questions, of course, and we have called for a full, credible and transparent investigation on that case.  Let me conclude that it is in the interests of all to foster a more transparent dialogue. There has been an intensification of this dialogue in the past weeks, and we trust that this will continue and allow for substantive progress on these very important files.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. (The sitting was suspended at 11.48 a.m. until the vote began)

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I will speak in English because I want you all to understand me on this. How can we talk about companies like Cambridge Analytica, which we accuse of having developed processes to influence elections in countries, but then we say nothing about the entities that produce rankings about the work of MEPs which are absolutely false, using shameful and subjective criteria, and can also influence the European Parliament election results in four months’ time? Who owns those entities? Who controls them? Who supervises them? Who develops the algorithms, and with what kind of motivations? I want to be clear. Entities like MEP Ranking are a shame for democracy, and Parliament should do something about it. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: Mr Melo, you are being clear but this is not a point of order. Can I just say, even though you have a great deal of support for that point, that it was not a point of order.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I rise under Chapter 5, Rule 82. I suggest, and I would like to request through the offices of the President, that the technology which we are about to vote on be put forward to Mr Barnier and the Brexit discussions and negotiators, because surely if this technology works, it could be a very important step forward in solving the problem of a hard border in Ireland, which is something that all of us in these negotiations wish to avoid. (The President cut off the speaker) (Reactions from the floor)

name: President. –
text: Really, colleagues, we can’t indulge in this. Can I just call the House to order. We’re in the middle of voting. Thank you. Madam, I can hear you but I’d rather not listen at the moment because I’m trying to chair votes. (Applause)

name: Georg Mayer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In accordance with Rule 59(3) of the Rules of Procedure in force here, I would ask you to put the amendments we have tabled and sent to you and the roll-call vote to the vote separately.

name: Eva Maydell
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, briefly, I just want to draw your attention to the fact that today, with this report, we abolish the so-called ‘roaming fees’ for cross-border payments. In this way, we (a) show to the European citizens that we can deliver fast and tangible results and (b) save them billions of euros annually. And not least, we also put the single market for payments at an equal footing, irrespective of whether you come from a eurozone country or non-eurozone country.  (Applause)

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report because, beyond establishing an accurate diagnosis of the effects patriarchal policies have on women, it focuses on the need to reverse policies of austerity and cuts that have caused so much pain to citizens in general and women in particular. It also proposes financial measures and mechanisms for implementing them. But I also intervene here to remember that progress is made through construction and collective organization. Together we are stronger and stronger, especially in the face of hateful messages than the far right pours on us. About the speeches of those who want us as reproductive machines at the service of the system. That's why, on March 8th, we're going on a feminist strike, as we did last year. Together, diverse, organized and increasingly and in more parts of the planet. Because we have motives. That's why we're going on strike.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask about this document: do we really want to promote the slaughter of unborn children to human rights and women's rights? I often hear here about the European Union as a successful project that ensures peace and prosperity in our region. yes, that's right, absolutely. Only then do I not understand why – when we live well in a rich part of the world – there is a fear of unborn and innocent children and we want to kill them, my question. Do unborn children really stand in the way of progress on equality between a man and a woman? Is this true? Is this what the European Parliament calls progressive social change? This? Then I certainly do not want such progress at the expense of defenceless and innocent children. Nor do I understand the huge fear of a different view. If someone in this chamber disagrees, for example, with the Istanbul Convention, which is a convention to combat violence against women - but beware, if he does not agree with it not because he approves of violence against women, but just disagrees with the convention for gender ideology it contains – then he is treated like an extremist and is going to fight it. So I ask where we have obtained the right to alienate The Member States for a family policy that promotes motherhood and parenthood.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – Mr President, every Member of this House has the right to put questions to the Commission. And communist MPs are proving that this is an important part of parliamentary scrutiny. In response to a question from my colleague Pimento López, two diametrically opposed motions for a resolution have emerged which illustrate the main reservation of left-wing Members towards parliamentary democracy. Parliament is the place where an agreement is sought, and they have no interest in finding such an agreement. In doing so, the agreement would help, in particular, for women whose rights the Member covers as a fig leaf when he asks the Commission to suppress a perception of the world and of man other than his own. I very much regret that we did not vote on an alternative resolution, which I would certainly support, because it respects the European Treaties in force and the principle of subsidiarity.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this question to the Commission because I note that, as the fight for gender equality and women's rights intensifies, more obstacles we are encountering along the way, which must be circumvented and eliminated once and for all. The emergence of nationalist regimes, the creation of administrative barriers in companies themselves and the limitation of women's access to education are just a few symptomatic examples of an unjust and uninclusive Europe that we have been watching and we do not want. To reverse this situation I believe that Member States should be the first to set an example, and this example is to ensure the fight against all forms of violence against women, including traditional pernicious practices and gender-based violence, as well as condemning sexist hate speech, phobic hate speech against LGBTI people , misogyny and online hate speech, including harassment and persecution. I would like to recall that both the transposition of the Istanbul Convention between The Member States and the final document of the Directive on work-life balance are fundamental to the establishment of a fair, inclusive and modern society. The European Union has an obligation to be at the forefront of this process.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I have strongly voted against this document because once again, under the mask of the legitimate objective of combating violence against women, new propaganda is being made. Again, outrageous, controversial topics related to the Istanbul Convention are promoted, again this hall is used and this grandstand for propaganda of various, so to put it, deviations.  In fact, all these documents are becoming a place for propaganda. We vote for North Sea fishing - LGBTI rights, we vote for dunes - LGBTI rights. This is wrong, unacceptable and inexplicable, Dear Mr President. Here it becomes a place of propaganda against traditional values and traditional family. It makes no sense and makes no sense to insert these contradictory contested texts into each of those documents. Among citizens, in particular our countries, there is no understanding that this propaganda needs to be made.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, once again I find myself having to rail against the almost mandatory pessimism of this Chamber. Everyone is always so gloomy about international trends, but the reality is my daughters are going to experience a life incomparably better than my mother did, just as hers was better than her grandmother’s. Globally, as in Europe, there has never been a time when women have been better fed, longer lived, better paid, more equally paid, less likely to die in childbirth and better educated than today. The driving force for that improvement has been the free market. A real backlash, if we have to talk in terms of backlash – as this report suggests – is not to equality, it is to the fact that every single proposal in this report is one that involves greater state intervention – either higher taxes or more power to Brussels, or in most cases both. Surely the best way to enlarge the freedom of women, as of men, is to recognise is that individualism and freedom are the basis of modern civilization.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the political challenges and strategies for women's cancer and related concomitant diseases. This important document calls for priority to be given to the fight against cancer in health policy and for the creation of a comprehensive Union strategy on cancer, and shows that, despite efforts to come, further, including appropriate diagnosis, treatment, but above all prevention, which also applies to massive and long-term hormonal contraception and hormonal stimulation associated with in vitro procedures under so-called sexual and reproductive health. It has recently been proven that long-term use of hormonal contraception may increase the risk of glioblastoma, as well as other types of cancer, in addition to the obvious effects of other harmful environmental factors that need to be eliminated.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As a co-rapporteur, I voted in favour of the resolution on the use of marijuana, where the medical purpose was to conduct clinical trials using marijuana-based medicines with appropriate resources. The resolution clearly distinguishes between marijuana-based medicinal products approved by regulators, medical marijuana not tested in clinical trials, and other marijuana uses. In addition, it calls for the removal of regulatory barriers that hinder research, while leaving Member States free to adopt the necessary solutions, although calls for more research and information to be provided. It is good that MEPs rejected the last-minute amendments tabled, as marijuana is not arugula lettuce, but a highly addictive variety crafted by various inventors, containing high concentrations of THC with traces of CBD protection, of which 700 have been added, and even 2300 according to some sources.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Mr President, medical use of cannabis is legal to some degree in 23 Member States of this Union, 47 states of the USA plus Washington DC, and a further 25 countries around the world. The list is growing. I am happy to support this resolution because regulation is the way, just as for any other product. However, I detect in this resolution, and in the words of some of the PPE Group speakers, a backdoor desire to strengthen prohibition – and that has utterly and completely failed: failed to protect young people, failed to address the real issues of addiction, and played into the hands of organised crime. This is the view of drug experts, addiction experts, and senior police officers. It is wrong to criminalise people with horrible illnesses, just as it’s wrong to criminalise addiction. Throughout the Union, we tolerate a much more dangerously addictive drug that wrecks lives. We call it beer, we call it whisky or we call it champagne, but we regulate alcohol because prohibition doesn’t work. It only makes things worse.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, this parliamentary question, this issue discussed in plenary on the use of cannabis for therapeutic purposes sparked some controversy in the networks. The people who defend the legalization of cannabis, both for therapeutic use and for the own use that each person wants to give him – for playful uses – are sometimes not understood. And that is why I would like to give an explanation of vote that the European Commission has an opportunity to support quality research on cannabis-based medicines, but it also has an opportunity at the moment to examine the funding provided for research in this area in the Ninth Framework Programme. In this sense, as we see that we Member States differ in perception, but also in legislation, it is a great opportunity to take advantage of, as Uruguay has done or as Canada has done.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this resolution mainly because the benefits to human health of the active principles found in the cannabis plant are today undeniable. Historically in Europe, this plant was banned due to the social consequences of its recreational abuse, but recently we realised that we were missing out on many treatment opportunities. As patients crave access to these treatments, pharmaceutical companies and cannabis producers are now racing to claim a share of a market that is deemed to be worth EUR 55 billion by 2028. Everyone’s concern is that legislators and competent authorities in Member States cannot keep pace in terms of regulation, leaving medical cannabis to slow-crawl its way into the market. We need to let research and development take its course, and pharmaceutical regulation do its part. I see no reason for these products not to be treated like any other medicine. The active principles from cannabis should be dealt with like all other active principles – and we can treat cannabis as we do other regulated plant-based medicines. The system for medicines already works well, and we have fought hard to make it fair across Europe. To conclude, we should leave aside our prejudices about the plant and believe that this is a new situation. There is no reason for these medicines not to follow the same evolution in science that is reflected in the fact that we now take aspirin whereas we used to chew on willow bark.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I wanted to support this report, but I could not. There is no reason for some people to forbid the other from eating something, to put something into their bodies. And for this reason, I did not want to vote against allowing marijuana, but on the other hand, the permit requires nothing more than the removal of the ban. And what do we have here? Again, this is our parliamentary talk, typical of this institution: with that in mind, instructing us to investigate it, not to investigate it, so as not to allow such marijuana. But why? Who cares, what do you mean? Just delete the ban and that's it. Besides, why do we only allow one type of marijuana, not another type of marijuana? After all, we hear slogans like "my belly, my business" here. That's why "my belly, my thing" only when you have to kill an unborn child, but if I want to eat something that someone else wants to forbid me, it's no longer "my belly, my business."
