And all of a sudden I have to go to the doctor for a prescription so that he lets me take something into my body. That is why I could not support this talked-through and overregulated report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as a doctor, I know that many medicines include both natural and synthetic substances, which, in greater quantities or improper use, harm and can also kill a person. However, with proper use, they help overcome illness or pain. However, we treat hemp in Slovakia with caution. It's a soft drug that affects brain activity, and we don't want it to be publicly available. It is right to allow its research to help patients suffering mainly from chronic pain. However, the cultivation and handling of hemp must be subject to strict regulations and contain fuses when spreading it outside the environment of a certified laboratory. At the same time, it must be ensured that such research is not misused for the uncritical popularisation of cannabis and light drugs.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I supported my colleague Ziele's report because its meaningful proposals protect the interests, rights and legitimate interests of carriers and owners from the Eastern European Union Member States.  Unlike the first report, from the first package of documents – the Mobility Package, where under pressure from Germany, France and Belgium, an attempt is made to steal, literally "stolen", taken over the business of eastern European countries. Entrepreneurs from Poland, Bulgaria, Romania, Hungary, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, even From Spain and Portugal are at risk. Their business model is under threat because decision-makers in Germany, France, Belgium are trying to steal this business. This is a vivid sign and example of a "double standard" and a breach of single market rules, which we must all fight against, because when we entered this Union we were told that the single common free market would be the decider. So this Mobility package must be suspended, withdrawn and returned for re-examination.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the resolution that I voted on today condemns the violent and disproportionate interventions of law enforcement against peaceful protesters. In particular, it condemns the use of non-lethal weapons, such as kinetic impact projectiles, tear gas grenades and the use of water cannons or tear gas cannons. These types of weapons were also used on 10 August 2018 by the Gendarmerie Romanian against hundreds of thousands of demonstrators demonstrating against the corruption of the PSD-ALDE Government. These protesting demonstrators were peaceful. It was also premeditated and carefully orchestrated by the Interior Ministry and the leaders of the governing coalition. Hundreds of people were seriously injured.  So far, those who have given orders to trigger violence against peaceful protesters and have also caused injuries have not been brought to trial. You have to answer to justice.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report on peaceful protest – a cherished right that we in the trade union movement hold dear. It is currently HeartUnions week when we show the love for trade unions because being a member of a union makes sense. Workers in unionised workplaces earn up to 10% more, enjoy greater job security and better terms and conditions. Getting successes nationwide, like the GMB deal for Hermes self-employed couriers to get holiday pay and Unison’s landmark case to scrap employment tribunal fees and — in the east of England, my region — UNITE helping scrap the plans to make Suffolk poultry catchers work on Christmas Day; and the successful FBU campaign to stop the PCC taking over Hertfordshire fire service; and fighting against injustices; Usdaw helping ‘Keep Sunday Special’ and the CWU fighting against crown post office closures. So, let’s get more bosses’ pulses racing by pumping up membership to help break heartbreak for workers.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by While the European Union is grapple with Brexit, the influx of illegal immigrants, the banking crisis in many Member States, the LIBE Committee, chaired by Mr Moraes, is stubbornly worthy of a better cause by the European Parliament on the rights of intersex people. In the fifth paragraph of the resolution, it calls on the Commission and the Member States to increase funding for civil society organisations dealing with intersex people. In the eleventh paragraph, it wants to force Member States to promote the rights of intersex people, including children. I consider such practices unacceptable, which is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I have to express my opinion on this and I cannot understand why the regressive Left of this Parliament wants us all to waste our time on resolutions that bring confusion, loss of dignity for individuals and fake rights. This is a medical issue, it’s not a political question. Babies born with deformed genitalia must be given the best healthcare and the problem must be resolved. There is no politics in this. A world-renowned geneticist has informed me that only one in 200 000 babies is born with this condition, and there is almost never any uncertainty about the true sex. If there were any, a simple chromosome test makes it crystal clear if it’s a boy or girl. So this is unscientific and manipulative on the part of some politicians and gender ideologists here. They want to confuse European citizens, brainwashing them into believing another human right is being denied. It’s not true. There is no Treaty competence for this, there is no political need for this and I am saddened that more people didn’t do their own research and vote against this terrible resolution.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, humanity advances when it protects all human beings equally. I voted in favour of this report so that the rights of LGBTI people are protected equally across Europe. And in the end of the Directive against discrimination, which has been blocked so far in the Council. LGBTI people suffer a lot because they are attacked, stigmatized, invisible, unrecognized. It is necessary to protect them because they are attacked by their identity, diversity, orientation or sexual characteristics. That is why I participate in the LGBTI Intergroup of the European Parliament to fight for their equality. Hate attacks by fascist groups have increased, although these are disparaged by the Catholic church and more conservative groups, who paint the design of the rainbow, the arch of the old woman. Members of my party's youth organisation will have to pay 3,000 euros, because to make a visibilizar is also attacking. For Galicia Nova my support within the European Parliament.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In its resolution on the list of actions for LGBTI people in point 3, Parliament calls on the Commission to give priority to lgbti actions in its 2019-2024 programme. In my opinion, the separation of this as a priority is a sign of discrimination and, on the other hand, one might ask why we should not prioritise heterosexual people. Equally bizarre is the eighth point. This is another one, I do not know which resolution on LGBTI. Question: is there really no more important issue in the European Parliament than dealing with some people's sexual tendencies all the time?

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The aim of the NAIADES programme mentioned by the President is to increase transport on inland waterways and thus to achieve a sustainable transport system for the European Union. Last December, the Council underlined the need to make fuller use of the potential of inland waterway transport. This is to enable this NAIADES III programme to be launched by the end of 2020. In its resolution voted on, Parliament calls for adequate funding for the programme. In my speeches, I have repeatedly stressed the importance of inland waterways, including the planned E40 waterway through my region, The Lublin Region. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution tabled.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, today we voted on a very curious report. A report of Parliament's own initiative calling for something as logical as law enforcement. Fourteen years ago, legislation has been passed to regulate the transport of live animals, both inside and outside the Union. Fourteen years later, It is Parliament itself that raises its voice to demand that these measures be implemented, which should alleviate the unspeakable suffering suffered by no less than one billion animals a year. A billion beings who feel, who suffer, who suffer. Can you get an idea? Is it too much to ask that the law be implemented, surveillance and sanctioned on those who do not comply? What are we legisling for, then? Is animal protection legislation a simple face wash? I understand that this neoliberal Europe, which today is letting those fleeing war die at sea, is not the Europe that will take us out of the animal hell we have turned this world into. Under no circumstances is it acceptable for us to export live animals to countries such as Turkey or Uzbekistan, not only because of the enormous distances and terrible conditions of the journey, but because outside of here there are no measures to lessen suffering at the time of slaughter. Why do we set rules in Europe but allow our animals to be sacrificed in any way? I only find one answer: "It's the market, folks." There's no more hypocrisy. If the rules don't apply it's simply because you don't want to. Because the industry doesn't want to. And although we voted in favour of this report, no, we do not like this regulation, because it is very uns ambitious. We are millions of people who ask for more, because an environmental, feminist and animalistic world is making its way into this age of desolation brought to us by capitalism, which turns everything, even life, into merchandise.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, well I do not think the regulation goes far enough and I think it is time for a ban on live exports for slaughter or fattening. I do welcome this report’s aim of stamping out weak enforcement. Many people in my country find the transport of life calves and sheep abhorrent. Of course, within the single market we cannot just ban it and some have therefore welcomed Brexit as a boon for animal welfare. They will, I believe, be heartily disappointed. Not only do we risk importing lower welfare agricultural products from places like the United States, who are decades behind European welfare standards, but we will also lose our influence within the EU. For 40 years we have used our votes, our economic strength and our political clout to help change policies, not just in Britain but across Europe, banning veal crates, battery cages and animal testing for cosmetics. Brexit will, I fear, be a step backwards for animal welfare, both in Britain and across all of Europe.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, which addresses the conditions of animals during transport. This situation is really catastrophic. Measurements in NGOs show that animals suffer in a huge way and that the legislation to date is not being used. In my opinion, however, the report is not very ambitious and there will need to be a serious debate in the future about whether we should ban the transport of live animals to third countries that do not respect the basic standards of animal life. I'm in for a ban like this.  Likewise, I think that in the future it will be necessary to adopt a clear regulation that limits the time it takes for a live animal to be transported to a slaughterhouse. There is talk of 8 hours, which I think is such a long time for which the animal can be taken to the slaughterhouse. Personally, I think that in the future, we need to support solutions so that the animal is put to sleep as close as possible to the place where it grows up, and that transports are limited as much as possible, to set tougher rules, but above all to control it.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to represent my colleague Anders Vistisen, who is unfortunately prevented from doing so. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent Today we are talking about the current threat to security from Iran. This is prompted by current events. In October 2018, for example, Danish Prime Minister Rasmussen stated that Iranian intelligence had planned an assassination attempt against three Iranian opposition figures living in Denmark. At the same time, the French government made similar accusations. In January 2019, German security forces arrested a german-Afghan Bundeswehr member on suspicion of leaking confidential military information to Iranian intelligence. The EU Council of Ministers has responded to these and other incidents. Accordingly, I fully welcome the Council of Ministers' resolution of 8 January 2019. The latter had decided that two Iranian nationals and the Directorate of Internal Security of the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence would be included in the EU's terror list. This is a clear signal that terror has nothing to do with German and European soil. In this context, I would also like to make an appeal to the Government of Iran: the Iranian Government must remember to do its part to resolve peacefully the many conflicts in the Middle East. Violence and terror will not achieve your goals in the long run. This applies to Iran as well as to all other actors pursuing their own interests in the Middle East. Iran is a strong military power; it should not be upgraded but disarmed. This applies in particular to its ballistic activities, which do not comply with the UN security resolution. Accordingly, the EU, the EU Member States must assume their responsibilities, must do their part to ensure peace in the Middle East.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome the opportunity to join you today and to discuss this very important topic: the recent hostile activities that Iran has reportedly conducted on the territory of several Member States. Let me start with the basic yet fundamental premise. The European Union has consistently voiced, and will continue to voice, our strong unequivocal condemnation of terrorism in all its forms and manifestations committed by whomsoever, wherever and for whatever purposes. It is then clear that in order to preserve our own European security, we cannot accept Iranian or any other country’s hostile activities on European soil, no matter the justification. There is complete solidarity between the European Union and all EU Member States on this issue, and this solidarity will continue. Whenever there have been reports of such activities, we have been in prompt contact with the authorities of the Member State concerned to offer our full support and solidarity. For example, in the case of Denmark at the end of last October, HR / VP Mogherini discussed the situation with the Danish Foreign Minister on the very same day that the case was made public. You will also be aware that the Foreign Affairs Council had two significant discussions on Iran in the final months of 2018. At the Foreign Affairs Council in November, the Danish Foreign Minister Anders Samuelsen provided an update and Member States underlined their solidarity and willingness to agree on measures to address this and other recent incidents on European territory. One month later in December, the Foreign Affairs Council again discussed Iran. Ministers agreed on the principle of adoption conclusions, which would reaffirm the commitment to the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), while making clear that it would not prevent the EU from raising concerns about Iranian activities. This solidarity at the Council led to the addition of two Iranian individuals and the Directorate for Internal Security of the Iranian Ministry for Intelligence and Security to the EU counter-terrorism list. The Council adopted the list on 9 January this year. Persons, groups and entities on this list are subject to the freezing of their funds and other financial assets, and European Union operators are prohibited from making funds and economic resources available to them. Our discussions on how we should collectively respond to threats to our security, whatever their provenance, did not end on that day, as the conclusions adopted on 4 February repeated that the European Union will continue to demonstrate unity and solidarity in this area. I would like to close these introductory remarks with three points. First, far from responding to policies of Iran with which we disagree, we have a number of restrictive measures in place against Iranian individuals and entities for reasons including their violation of human rights, support for terrorism and support for the Assad regime. Secondly, we should resist the temptation of viewing any country as solely a perpetrator of terrorism. Iran too has been a victim of terror attacks and consistency demands that we have also condemned, as in the case of the attacks in Ahvaz in September last year, which claimed the lives of at least 25 individuals. Finally, our vigorous response to these actions, while necessary, should not affect the EU’s continuing commitment to the full and effective implementation of the JCPOA whose preservation is in the security interests of the EU and the international community. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to our discussion.

name: Jiří Pospíšil
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I have listened carefully to your speech. I must say, I am more skeptical of the Iranian regime than you are. For me, this is a totalitarian regime that, by taking action on EU citizens on EU territory, confirms that it cannot be a credible partner of the EU. The murders of EU citizens that have taken place here, for which the Iranian regime is very likely to be responsible, are something completely unacceptable and we cannot close our eyes to this simply because there are certain commitments, agreements, including the nuclear arms agreement. I am much more sceptical in this regard, unlike Mrs Mogherini and some members of the European Commission.  What is at least important, and I welcome that, is that you have adopted certain sanctions against certain members of the intelligence services of the Iranian regime. It is essential that the individual Member States do not stand alone with Iran in the fight against the murder of EU citizens, but that the EU as a whole responds to such acts of hostility within the EU. I think this is very important, this is not a problem for individual Member States, where either these violent crimes have taken place or it has been suspected that these crimes are being prepared there by members of the Iranian intelligence services. And in the future, please proceed with this forceful action against the perpetrators, but also the entire regime.

name: Andrejs Mamikins
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we condemned any unlawful activities of foreign intelligence services on European soil, including from Iran.  However, the purpose of this interpellation is not to resolve our disagreements with Iran, which are many, but to sabotage the EU efforts to keep engagement with Iran alive. This is happening at a time when the EU is doing its utmost to save the nuclear agreement with Iran. This agreement serves its purpose of ensuring that Iran's nuclear programme is exclusively peaceful. Iran delivered on its commitments, as confirmed by 14 reports of the International Atomic Energy Agency. The EU has to deliver its side of the deal by offering Iran economic dividends to which it is entitled as part of the agreement. This is why the EU created a special mechanism to facilitate legitimate trade with Iran. I fully support that mechanism and hope that it will deliver real results.  The purpose of this debate, to the contrary, is to create a negative environment in EU-Iran relations and to undermine the efforts at engagement, led by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini. The initiators of this debate attempt to depict Iran as the only source of all trouble in the Middle East. Although we have disagreements with Iran on a number of issues, it is unacceptable and unrealistic to blame only Iran for all the instability and violence in the region. This debate is about State support of terrorism. No country fits the bill more than Saudi Arabia. This Parliament recognised the Saudi-originated Wahhabism as a key security threat for Europe as far back as in 2013. Today we voted on a resolution condemning Saudi Arabia for human rights violations and also for the troubling role it plays in the region.  The Commission has just come out with a proposal to include Saudi Arabia in its blacklist of countries that do not do enough to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. The Commission says that Saudi Arabia represents a high risk for the integrity of Europe's financial system. It is absurd to discuss terror threats and not to discuss Saudi Arabia. We need serious debate on this issue and not propaganda events at the service of ideological obsessions.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this week Iran noisily celebrated the 40th anniversary of the Islamic Revolution. During these last 40 years, international terrorism has become a prominent feature of Iran’s foreign policy and has produced a bloody history of terror attacks. Iran’s theocrats not only use Shia jihadists in Iraq and Syria, and support terrorist organisations like Hezbollah or rebel movements in Yemen, but also spread their radical ideology via their support for religious studies centres and NGOs in the Balkans and, violently, via terrorist plots on European soil to assassinate regime opponents. Regardless of my support for the negotiations around the Iran nuclear deal and the establishment of mechanisms like the Instrument in Support of Trade Exchanges (INSTEX) special-purpose vehicle, unfortunately I believe that those negotiations and mechanisms do not alter in any way Iran’s unacceptable behaviour: its support for terrorism, its willingness to expand its ballistic missile programme and its horrific record of violating human rights. The recent Iranian-backed campaign of assassinations and terror plots on European soil poses a serious threat to our security and must incur targeted consequences diplomatically and economically.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I congratulate Colleague Kölmel on this issue. There is no doubt terrorism must be prosecuted everywhere. No one in this room will support any organization or country that supports, supports and develops terrorism. On the other hand, I am convinced that we must respect the right of every nation to order its own order. We cannot blame one country, one nation, one nation, one government, call them all terrorists. I believe no one does, I'm sure it's not.  European Union, European countries have a huge commercial and economic interest in maintaining good relations with the Republic of Iran. It is no coincidence that Germany, France and other European countries maintain such relations. I'm sure we should do it. name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission: "A Europe that protects: clean air for all" by Julie Girling, Seb Dance, Jadwiga Winiewska, Catherine Bearder, Keith Taylor, Anja Hazekamp, Eleonora Evi on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000138/2018 – B8-0009/2019).

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Vella, I am indeed very honoured today to table the oral question entitled 'A Europe that protects: clean air for all', on behalf of the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. I believe that the debate we are about to hold today, thanks to this question, will further stimulate the initiatives that are being taken, especially outside this House, to improve air quality for the benefit of all. In the same way, I believe that the resolution, which is linked to this oral question, is also very important, and therefore the message that the European Parliament will be able to send out in March thanks to its adoption at the next plenary session. Air quality is an issue of increasing interest to european public opinion. We are talking about a general problem which affects in a tangible way the 500 million citizens we represent here and who would like to see it resolved as soon as possible. Certainly in the society in which we live air pollution is a cause for strong and widespread concern, together with the adverse weather events that are taking place on the continent with increasing force due to climate change. At present, the price paid for poor air quality in our cities in terms of human lives is higher than that caused by road accidents. With over 400 000 premature deaths per year, air pollution is unfortunately the leading environmental cause of premature deaths in Europe. The particularly critical situation in urban settings, where the greatest number of European citizens live. According to the available data, 19 % of the urban population is continuously exposed to fine dust levels above the daily limit values established by Union legislation. In addition, about half of europe's population is exposed to concentrations of these substances more than the more stringent recommendations made so far by the World Health Organisation. Breathing clean air is therefore essential, not only to protect the health of our fellow citizens, but also to ensure the maintenance of a healthy environment for the benefit of present and future generations. Poor air quality has a detrimental impact on the maintenance of ecosystem services. Excess atmospheric nitrogen, in particular, damages the ecosystem, favoring the eutrophication of the atmosphere and the appearance of acid rain. It is precisely for this reason that, since the beginning of the 1970s, the European Union has embarked on a path of establishing common rules to control the release of harmful substances into the atmosphere and thus to improve the quality of fuels and thus to integrate environmental protection requirements in the transport and energy production sectors. Air pollution, however, goes beyond national borders, and that is why the coordination at Union level of actions aimed at improving air quality is of truly remarkable importance. However, although Europe has a solid and uniform legislative framework to combat air pollution, the environmental policy measures and instruments adopted in the Member States and at local, regional and national level vary enormously from one context to another, from one Member State to another. The fact that there are serious problems with the implementation of air quality legislation is demonstrated by the very large number of pre-contentious procedures initiated over the years by the European Commission. Today there are 30 infringements under way concerning the poor application of the rules that should protect the health of European citizens from air pollution. It is therefore more necessary than ever to act urgently to improve the air we breathe in Europe, ensuring compliance with the ambient air quality standards that the European Parliament and the governments of the Member States adopted more than ten years ago.  The message we are sending to the Commission today through our question is precisely this: we ask it to step up its efforts to closely monitor, in particular, the implementation of Directive 2008/50/EC, the rules governing industrial emissions, those relating to the transport sector and the type-approval of vehicles. We ask you to give serious consideration to the need to respond to the specific needs of regional and local authorities, which we must strongly support so that they can take effective and systematic measures to reduce transport emissions, including through increased opportunities for cofinancing in particular under the programmes. linked to the next Multiannual Financial Framework. Finally, we call on you to act within the framework of the reform of the common agricultural policy, in order to give farmers the means to help them reduce emissions from their sector, in particular ammonia emissions, and to address the growing human health concerns related to exposure to ultrafine particulate matter.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, in May of last year the Commission adopted a communication on a Europe that protects clean air for all. In this communication, we outlined the EU clean air policy approach, provided examples of measures to reduce air pollution in the transport, power and heat energy industry, and also in the agricultural sectors. We also point to initiatives taken to step-up cooperation with Member States, with regions, and also with cities. Against this background let me reply to your five questions. First on the first question, the Commission has been taking decisive action where it sees persistent exceedances above air quality limit values. It is currently pursuing 30 infringement procedures against 20 Member States for exceedances of particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide or sulphur dioxide limit values. In two cases, the Court of Justice has already ruled against the Member States. The Commission will continue to actively manage the infringement process as fast as possible, including referrals to the court where and when warranted.  With regards to your second question, as you know, the Commission is carrying out a fitness check of the Ambient Air Quality Directives. We initiated this in 2017 and will complete it in the second half of this year. Its findings will be used to inform further reflections on whether these directives continue to provide the appropriate legislative framework to ensure protection from adverse impacts on, and risks to, human health and the environment. However, as the analysis is not yet over, it would be premature to anticipate now the conclusions the Commission might draw.  Referring to question three, European Union funding under various financial streams has been made available and successfully used by Member States to address the air quality challenge. In the current programing period – that is 2014 to 2020 – EUR 1.8 billion have been directly allocated to support air quality measures under the European Structural and Investment Fund.  In addition, further indirect contributions beneficial to clean air come from investments in the low-carbon economy and environmental protection and resource efficiency, or in the transport network infrastructure. More specifically, to support regions and cities, in the urban agenda for the EU there have been innovative actions to further facilitate addressing air pollution in urban areas where transport is one of the main sources of air pollution.  Looking ahead for the period post-2020, the Commission has proposed under the Cohesion Policy a particular emphasis on a green low carbon Europe including a specific result indicator on population benefiting from measures for air quality.  On question number four, the agricultural sector is an important source of ammonia emissions, which in turn are a key precursor to particulate matter. Measures to mitigate these emissions include agronomic measures, livestock measures, or energy production measures. They are already available, technically and economical viable, and should be applied more widely.  According to the Commission's proposal for a new Common Agricultural Policy after 2020, one of the impact indicators to assess the performance of this policy explicitly refers to the ammonia emissions from agriculture. To be more specific, a result indicator will measure the share of agricultural land under commitments to reduce ammonia emissions. On the fifth question, EU legislation sets objectives for ambient air quality, taking into account the relevant scientific information provided via the World Health Organisation, which is the World’s leading authority on health matters. Their air quality guidelines establish the most authoritative, scientific basis to date. The World Health Organisation keeps the scientific basis under regular review, including ultra-fine particles and black carbon. In addition, it is currently working towards an update of these air quality guidelines. The Commission is following this work very closely.

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent replies. According to the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, more than 100 million Europeans suffer from allergic rhinitis and 70 million from asthma. Also, the European Respiratory Society has warned that even short-term increases in air pollution have been associated with respiratory symptoms and temporary decreases in lung function. In projections by the OECD, air pollution will be the biggest environmental cause of premature deaths by 2050. Millions of Europeans live in areas where simply breathing the air around them is damaging to their health, and these effects should not be underestimated. Air pollution can reduced lifespans and cause serious heart and lung disease. The pollutants of most concern for human health across Europe are airborne particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide and ground-level ozone. These pollutants increase the death rate, especially in sensitive population groups such as the elderly and those suffering from respiratory diseases. Despite these health impacts, current EU legislation permits levels of damaging pollutants higher than those recommended by the World Health Organisation. What still needs to be done? Member States should reinforce their efforts to tackle sources of pollution from all sectors. States also need to improve cooperation on cross—border pollution, make air quality an integral part of their policies, and ensure that the correct level of governance – national, regional or municipal – is equipped to tackle sources of pollution. I recently hosted an exhibition in Parliament celebrating Lisbon as 2020 European Green Capital, a designation for which one of the 12 criteria evaluated was air quality. In the past 10 years, Lisbon has shown a significant decrease in emissions from most pollutants, resulting in a significant improvement in air quality. By limiting polluting vehicles in the city, without reducing mobility, and by planning green corridors that act as a ventilation system, Lisbon was able to achieve its aim on air quality. Commissioner, we need more examples like Lisbon and we need national strategies for air quality.

name: Christel Schaldemose
text: for the S&D Group. Mr President! Thank you, Mr President, and also thank you, Commissioner, for the answers to our questions. I would like to admit that I may be a little bit disappointed. I have no doubt that the current Commission is concerned about air quality and is doing something, but I also think we need to make even clearer what needs to happen. Air pollution kills – I repeat: air pollution kills! The assessment is that every year here in the EUROPEAN Union, 4 000 000 of our citizens die prematurely as a result of air pollution. This is deeply serious! That is why we also need to do something. I fully recognise what the Commission has done, but we also need to do much more. We have to dare to talk about the difficult things about this. What's hard? Yes, we need to point out that, for example, agriculture must also contribute. Agriculture must reduce their air pollution, both in relation to CO2, ammonia and methane gas. Unfortunately, agriculture is an essential part of our problem. We must dare to talk about this, we must dare to talk about using our agricultural policy and our agricultural subsidies to pressure agriculture to contribute to the solution. Then there is the transport sector. It is still part of this. And yes, fortunately we have a lot of legislation in the way. We have done something, but we can do even more. There is still plenty to follow up on top of Dieselgate, which is still there – it is 11 Member States that are asked to be allowed to pollute something more, to have their limit values set up. That's not okay! We need to tighten up, also in relation to the transport sector. We need to also give our cities in Europe the opportunity to do more. Fortunately, I know that the Commission also supports this, but we need to ensure that cities have the right to also create environmental zones and to take every possible effort to protect their urban citizens from this very harmful pollution. I hope that the present Commission will help to lay a very good foundation so that over the next five years we can really tackle this problem of air pollution in earnest. We must ensure that air pollution is reduced so that people do not die from it.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The debate is entitled 'Clean air for all' – who would disagree! But we have to be careful on such issues that we do not throw the baby out with the bathwater. In 2008, this Parliament voted in favour of limit values, for example in the field of nitrogen dioxide. 40 micrograms per cubic metre of air was set for public transport. In the end, that was a seized value. That has to be said quite clearly. And this value is therefore effective and therefore, in principle, meaningless, because we have different limit values for many areas. How can we explain that 40 micrograms are set for public transport, but 950 micrograms are allowed in the workplace? There is something wrong with that! And if I read reports these days that I had well over 100 micrograms of this stuff in my breath at Christmas because I had four Christmas candles burned, then that must give us food for thought. I maintain that we are travelling here on a level that cannot be substantiated by facts. And I must confess, I cannot understand at all that the previous speakers have said 'so and so many people die prematurely because we have various toxins in the air'. The fact is, thank God, that people are getting older. That's fine! But how can we then deduce that we have a great many premature deaths that cannot be proven scientifically at all? Normally, we like to refer to California, which has very high environmental standards. But even California has a limit value for nitrogen dioxide that is 40% higher than that in the EU. Instead, we should actually look at the Pareto principle again. The Italian scientist of the same name had already found in the Middle Ages that it takes as much effort to achieve the first 80% of a problem solution as it does for the last 20%.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to ask you, do you know that Brussels and Strasbourg, the two cities where we live and work, are among the most polluted cities? Let's start at the Parliament building in Brussels and put units of measure and displays here for these units of measurement. For us to start by ourselves because when I watch these joggers and cyclists around Brussels running and breathing that air, I feel sorry for them. Let's start with the European Parliament, from the European Parliament building in Brussels and Strasbourg.  I'll add two more problems.  Cross-border pollution. In Croatia we have concrete cross-border pollution from Bosnia and Herzegovina. Slavonski Brod is often so polluted that people just don't go out on the street. Let's do something.  Agriculture, I agree, is an additional problem. Let's motivate biodynamic agriculture, motivate bio-agriculture and there will be fewer problems.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. "Mr President," Said George Orwell, that we have fallen so low that reformulate the obvious is the first obligation of an intelligent person. Discussing clean air and the need to live in uncontainable environments corresponds to this state of unquestionable no-brainer for all. According to the European Environment Agency, air pollution is responsible for 422,000 premature deaths each year. The economic impact is considerable: 4 billion in health expenditures and more than 3 billion in agricultural crop yield losses. The impact in environmental terms is likely to be even greater when we consider difficult-to-quantification facts: the impact of acid rain on soils, the loss of biodiversity caused by pollution, pollution of water resources, and so on. The causes of these processes are sufficiently known. Among them, a first and fore all is road traffic and in cities. Indeed, it is worrying to know that more than 76% of the European population lives in cities exposed to pollution rates higher than the maximum permitted standards. We share and support the Commission's efforts in this area, through the Clean Air for Europe programme, but the reality of the data stubbornly shows the departure from the initial outlook in a clearly negative direction. It is the responsibility of States, regional entities, and especially local entities, to increase efforts in this area. But when we come to the moment when the authorities are committed to this issue and are about to fight air pollution, the usual interests arise and the political representatives of those interests arise. For example, Madrid. The opposition and hostility that is being demonstrated in the face of the Plan A project to combat pollution is truly regrettable. The People's Party, which governs in the Community of Madrid, is opposing precisely reducing pollution by 20.4%, which is what has already been done in the first month of the Plan. Of course, we are in a situation where we must move from fact-friendly statements, from hollow statements to compromised public policies, and to point out those who serve the interests of industries and are also indirectly responsible for the deaths of nearly half a million Europeans each year.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am taking the floor again in this debate, now on behalf of my political group and the 5-Star Movement, because I believe that this is a fundamental issue and the right to breathe clean air is unfortunately denied to many, very many citizens in Europe and throughout the world. Breathing clean air today is not just a reality, it should be an objective to aspire to and for which politics must do more. It must do more because more than 4.2 million people die in the world every year as a result of air pollution and, according to WHO data, 91 % of the global population live in places where air quality is precisely below standard. As far as Europe's figures are concerned, we have talked about this earlier. The situation is certainly serious and more needs to be done. I personally come from a region, lombardy and in particular Northern Milan, which has the black jersey because of air pollution due to the very high overruns and concentrations of fine dust and nitrogen oxides, and this is because citizens suffer from the unholy choices of a regional government that unfortunately looks to particular and private interests with regard to the collective good and the protection of the collective interest. We have all too often seen the right to breathe clean air sacrificed on the altar of huge, useless infrastructure projects, which are aimed precisely at private interests, causing the environment to go down. We have mutilated our territory and destroyed beautiful areas that are also present in Lombardy. I, as a citizen and spokesman for the 5-Star Movement, however, believe that not everything is lost, that a Europe that protects can be possible and must be sought and must be built together. We demonstrate this through the legislative action we are taking both in Brussels and in Rome, by supporting a fair but ambitious transformation of many sectors, I am thinking of the automotive sector and the transport sector, trying to put them as much as possible on a model of spreading zero- and low-emission vehicles and local public transport. I would also like to thank you, Commissioner, for the clean air dialogues that you have introduced, and I would also like to thank you for taking a stand against the diesel defenders who have really done so lately... name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think it has already been made clear here what a major problem the poor air quality is. If 400 000 people die or less every year, it does not matter in principle, it is a huge problem, a huge problem for Europe, and we must therefore tackle it.  What is important and what needs to be said, and the Commissioner has already said this, is that a revision of the directive is being done at the moment to address the issues of ambient air quality. I am very much looking forward to the report that is to be made this year, Commissioner, in order to see how this directive works and where the Commission therefore foresees its improvement. It is likely to be a job for the new Commission, which will come on the basis of the European elections. This should be a key task, certainly environmental issues will also be the subject of an election campaign in the spring of this year, and the next Commission should therefore take into account the evaluation of the current legislation and propose concrete solutions.  But it must also be said that the current arrangements, which – as most colleagues have said – are not sufficient, so not all countries are fulfilling it. According to the latest report, 18 Member States are currently not meeting the emission limits already set. And that's a big problem. We have some legislation that we want to improve, but we have to admit that the current legislation is not being met. And here I think that we can either go the way of going to the European Court of Justice and suing individual states, but that will take years and it will not solve anything, or there is probably a need for a stronger political dialogue between the Member States and between the European Commission and more exhortations for Member States to do more to meet the limits that are already in place at the moment. If we come up with new better legislation, but the Member States do not comply with it, we will still be in the problem that is here. Almost half a million deaths a year from dirty air. So, please, let the Commission propose new amendments, but also put pressure on the Member States to do what is binding today.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, I thank my colleagues who have raised this question on clean air and I also welcome the Commission's Clean Air for All communication.  The question proposal discusses easier access by regional and local units to financial funds to combat transport emissions, but I don't think there's any need to limit ourselves to traffic emissions only. Emissions from buildings for heating and cooling, emissions from energy plants, emissions from industry are also very high. I think they should also be put into this question, that is, to demand an answer. I think it will need to change the directive at the very least to comply with the new energy laws that we have adopted this year and at the very least in terms of measuring air pollution reporting.  I would like to draw attention to the particular problem facing the Western Balkans. The cities of Sarajevo and Skopje in some parts of the year are the most polluted cities, not of Europe, but of the world. There are 16 thermal power plants working on coal with outdated technologies, and new ones are planned, also with outdated technologies. This of course affects the health of the people who live there, but also the health of citizens in the neighbouring member states of the European Union. Therefore, high standards should be respected, but also help these countries to respect high air purity standards themselves.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I congratulate Colleague Evie first on this issue, it is important because it affects the health of an awful lot of people. From dirty air they get sick, get sick, lose their lives an awful lot of people. But I would like to draw your attention to one of the causes of air pollution, namely the burning of tires, panties, rags and all sorts of other rubbish in a number of gypsy neighborhoods in many eastern and central European countries. This is a huge problem that is not recognized anywhere, it is not talked about. It's s carpeted. name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you, colleagues, for putting the issue of clean air for all on the agenda. It is one of the most important environmental and health challenges of our time. Our citizens expect us to solve this issue and ensure that the air we breathe every day is of good quality and does not leave us at risk of harm. And they expect us to solve this together. With regard to the implementation, this Commission has been very active in promoting air quality and supporting a shift to cleaner air, as recently recalled in the ‘Clean air for all’ communication of last May. As in every piece of legislation, implementation is more than important – it is key. The Commission expects all Member States to take all necessary measures to achieve compliance with EU air quality limits as soon as possible. The limit of 40 milligrams per cubic metre of NO2 as an annual average is an EU-wide obligation and has been agreed by all Member States. This obligation must be complied with by all Member States for the benefit of all our citizens. And here I would like to refer to our current air quality standards. Some say they are too strict and others say they are not strict enough. Ultimately there can only be one test. Do they meet the goal of protecting human health and the environment as a whole from the risk of adverse impacts? And to assess this, there can only be one yardstick. The best available and thoroughly peer-reviewed scientific advice. Regarding agriculture, the contribution of agriculture to the issue of ammonia emissions has, I agree, to be addressed as well. Through the NEC (National Emissions Ceiling) Directive we have started to do just that. On monitoring stations across the European Union, around 4 000 monitoring stations provide us with reliable, credible and comparable information on air quality, often in almost real time. We see no systematic shortcomings in the way the criteria to establish monitoring that works as set out in the directives have been applied. But when we see that monitoring is not done in line with the requirements of the directives, the Commission has to act and will continue to act. Allow me to conclude with a final reference to our ongoing fitness check, which we will conclude this year. This will provide us with a basis to reflect on whether we have the appropriate legislative framework in place, including sufficiently stringent limit values and suitably clear criteria to guide our monitoring networks, to ensure protection from adverse impacts on, and the risks to, human health and the environment. And, finally, to really deliver a Europe that protects.
